description:
Regional Government of Castilla and Leon published a document on March 11 according to which the teaching practices in health and socio-health centers for students of vocational training cycles and university degrees are suspended, with the exception of those in the last year of studies in medicine and nursing who express their express consent in writing.

This policy ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19. UPDATE: The original policy was supposed to end on March 26, but it actually ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020  that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On March 12, the Generalitat of Valencia ordered the suspension of schools, universities and nurseries in the province. School teachers still have to go to their educational centers and it’s up to the directors to decide if they can work from home. This policy will enter into force on the 13th of March 2020 and does not have an end date. UPDATE: On March 14, the National Government of Spain announces a nationwide state of emergency. Due to this, all educational centers are forced to close under a national government mandate. This new national mandate replaces the previous where the Valencian Community mandated school closings.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description:
On March 12, the region of Castilla y Leon ordered the suspension of schools, universities and nurseries in the province. School teachers still have to go to their educational centers and it’s up to the directors to decide if they can work from home. This policy will enter into force on the 13th of March 2020 and does not have an end date.
 UPDATE: On March 14, the National Government of Spain announces a nationwide state of emergency. Due to this, all educational centers are forced to close under a national government mandate. This new national mandate replaces the previous where the Castilla y Leon Community mandated school closings.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)

description:
Government of Castilla and Leon published a document on March 13 where face-to-face teaching and extracurricular activities are suspended in centers of all educational levels. Regarding the university sphere, classroom teaching activity is also suspended and public and private university residences are closed, except for those foreign students who, due to force majeure, cannot return to their countries of origin and students who live with people at risk.
During the period of suspension of face-to-face teaching, it is recommended to continue the activities through the distance and online modalities.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
institution_status: Higher education institutions closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

The formalities and procedures will resume when the Royal Decree, and the possible extensions, are repealed.

description: On March 12, the Prime Minister of Spain Pedro Sanchez recommends shutting down all educational centers for the next two weeks. This new national mandate replaces the previous, Andalucia mandated school closings.

The government of Aragon agreed to follow this recommendation. Therefore, in all of Aragon's territory, all educational activity is suspended, as well as face-to-face university activities in all centers and stages, cycles, degrees, courses and levels of education. During the suspension period, educational activities will be maintained through distance and online modalities, whenever possible.

description: From March 14, 2020, the government of Spain implemented a closure and regulation of Schools that will affect all the regions of Spain. The government of Aragon agreed to follow this recommendation. Therefore, in all of Aragon's territory, all educational activity is suspended, as well as face-to-face university activities in all centers and stages, cycles, degrees, courses and levels of education. During the suspension period, educational activities will be maintained through distance and online modalities, whenever possible.

description: On May 4, Andalusia enters Phase 0 of Spains deescalation plan. This means that how quickly the region is able to move through the deescalation plan, and therefore alter the restrictions put in place on educational facilities, depends on the Andalusian government. Therefore, all educational updates within the deescalation period will be coded subnationally.

description: In Catalonia, on May 5, 2020 it was announced that the universities will open again. The occupation of work areas and classrooms will be reduced to 25% of its current capacity in the early stages and may gradually increase to 50%. The limitation of space will make it necessary to reduce face-to-face teaching between 50% and 25%, while the rest of the classes will be held online.

description:
From May 20,2020, the Department of Education has prepared an opening plan for educational centers in Catalonia for the end of the current academic year and for the next academic year 2020-2021.
Regarding the dates of application of the plan in each center, they must be adapted to the progressiveness of the arrival of Phase 2 in each territory. 
-Nurseries, maximum 5 students per classroom. 
-Kindergarten and primary schools, maximum 13 students per group.
-ESO centers and post-compulsory education, in groups of 15 students maximum.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Number of people on the school premises are limited (e.g. only 50 people allowed on school premises),Types of people on school premises are limited (e.g. no parents),Regular cleaning and sanitary procedures applied to classrooms (e.g. classrooms must be aired out after each class),Special provisions exist for some students in a school  (e.g. students living with essential workers can attend school while others must stay home)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Education,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On June 8, The Castilla and Leon Community enters Phase 2 of Spain de-escalation plan. Due to this, kids up to six years old could go to the education center with a maximum level of 33% of its total capacity. Students of last academic years could go to the education center only if they want, but respecting a maximum capacity of 15 people. Open-air spaces should be available for children. Mask wearing and keeping a 2 metres distance between children are required. Therefore, all educational updates within the de-escalation period will be coded sub nationally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)

description: On June 11, the Spanish Ministries of Health and Education and Professional Training release a document, agreed upon by the autonomous communities, that declares a strategy "to offer a safe and healthy environment for students and staff of educational centers in order to resume face-to-face activity for the 2020-2021 academic year that begins in September." This strategy fundamentally revolves around "contact limitation, personal prevention measures, case management, and cleaning and ventilation."

description: Ximo Puig, president of Generalitat Valenciana, informed that on July 19, schools of the Valencian Community for kids up to 3 years old (i.e. preschool, kindergarten), whether public or private, can reopen and resume their activity. Also, summer schools can open with 75% of the normal student number (maximum capacity is 100 in closed spaces and 250 in opened ones). Additionally, elementary, middle and high schools must provide face-to-face tutoring to families by appointment. Also, they can carry out face-to-face activities in small groups for students who take the university entrance exams. Finally, university students can resume their internships.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Physical classroom hours or meeting times reduced (e.g. classes only meet in the morning; classes meet every other day)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On June 30, it is announced that "the Junta of Andalucia... will hire 6,300 extra teachers" for the 2020-2021 school year. These teachers will "serve as 'support' in schools with more than 20 students per classroom." In addition to the 6,300 teachers, 1,600 cleaners, alog with 152 "technical staff for social integration," will be hired. This initiative, combined with other general investments to improve the education system for the upcoming year (such as the Andalucian government giving 25 million pounds to schools "to expand or renovate their facilities and make them ready for emergencies") will cost the government around 600 million pounds.

description:
In the Community of Madrid, Spain, starting July 1, 2020, students in the first cycle of child education may return to classrooms voluntarily, with preference for children whose parents must work outside the home. Daycare centers will continue to offer services that they have been offering since March 11.

University education will remain remote, but if an activity requires physical presence, a distance of 1.5 meters must be maintained. Universities must approve an action plan for the 2020-21 academic year.

If the case is simply suspected, only the person in question will go into quarantine until the results of a PCR test comes back negative. The schools will  also have to close down entirely if there are two positive cases in two different groups.

description: On March 28, the city of Lozoyuela-Navas-Sieteiglesias in the Community of Madrid, Spain, initiated a curfew after 3 pm. People were only allowed out of the house from 9 am-3 pm, and all purchases needed to be at least 30 euros. The curfew began on March 28. No information is provided on an end date.
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: The Spanish Health ministry announces on April 30 that starting from May 2, Spanish citizens aged 14-70 years are allowed to go out for a walk or exercise from 6 to 10 am and from 8 to 11 pm. The outing has to take place within one km from home (individual exercise excluded), with a distance of 2m from other people. Individuals under this demographic can go with max. 1 person living in the same household. In villages with less than 5000 inhabitants the different time frames don’t apply, everyone can go out under the same conditions between 6am and 11pm.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: The Spanish Health ministry announces on April 30 that starting from May 2, Spanish citizens aged 14-69 years are allowed to go out for a walk or exercise from 6 to 10 am and from 8 to 11 pm. The outing has to take place within one km from home (individual exercise excluded, as you only have to stay within your municipality), with a distance of 2m from other people. Individuals under this demographic can go with max. 1 person living in the same household. In villages with less than 5000 inhabitants the different time frames don’t apply, everyone can go out under the same conditions between 6am and 11pm.

description: The Spanish Health ministry announces on April 30 that starting from May 2, people who need special attention and people aged 70+ can go out between 7-8 pm accompanied by one person. The outing has to take place within one km from home, with a distance of 2m from other people. This time slot is in tandem with the 10-12 am time slot, with both acting as viable options for outside activity under this demographic. In villages with less than 5000 inhabitants the different time frames don’t apply, everyone can go out under the same conditions between 6am and 11pm.
type_sub_cat: No the curfew times are always the same regardless of the day of the week
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 25, the Prime Minister of Spain announces that, starting May 2, people 14 or older (but less than 70/ not dependent) can take one-hour walks, accompanied by one person, once a day within half a mile of their homes, or do sports like riding a bike alone within their city. The timeframe set for this activity is between 6 a.m. to 10 a.m. (or 8 p.m. to 11 p.m.).

description: Extremadura, Spain is regulating walks and other physical exercise in public areas through timetables from May 2, 2020 until Extremadura enters Phase 1 on May 11, 2020. For walks with children: from 12 pm to 7 pm. “They can only go out accompanied by a parent or carer, or older sibling, as previously permitted. Walks involving the whole family are still not allowed. In a family with two parents and two under 14s, the parents could technically go out for a walk together in the times allocated to adults, providing the children are mature enough to be left alone at home; the four of them would not, however, be permitted to go out together during the times for children. Walks are limited to a kilometer from the residence.” There may be checks on people’s behaviors but details are unknown.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: No the curfew times are always the same regardless of the day of the week
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry),Other population not specifed above

description: Extremadura, Spain is regulating walks and other physical exercise in public areas through timetables from May 2, 2020 until Extremadura enters Phase 1 on May 11, 2020. For those aged 14 and over: from 6am to 10am. “If people opt for a walk, they can do so with one other person with whom they live, but they can go no further than a one kilometer radius of their residence. This restriction does not apply to those practicing sport, such as running or cycling, who must practice these activities alone and stay within their municipality.” There may be checks on people’s behaviors but details are unknown.

Only one outing a day is allowed for one hour maximum, and the outing has to take place within one km from home. In villages with less than 5000 inhabitants, these time frames don’t apply, and everyone can go out under the same conditions between 6am and 11pm.

 UPDATE: To coordinate with the deescalation of outside regulation for other demographics, the Spanish Health ministry announces on April 30 that starting from May 2, children under 14 are allowed to go out between 12-7 pm, accompanied by a parent. Only one outing a day is allowed. Children are allowed to stay out for one hour maximum. The outing has to take place within one km from home , with a distance of 2m from other people. Adults can go with max. 1 person living in the same household. In villages with less than 5000 inhabitants the different time frames don’t apply, everyone can go out under the same conditions between 6am and 11pm.

description:
On April 25th, the Spanish government announces that, starting April 26th, “up to three children under the age of 14 accompanied by an adult, guardian or elder sibling … are now … allowed out for an hour a day to walk and exercise” between 9am and 9pm, with 2m social distancing required.
 UPDATE: In accordance with the curfews for additional demographics starting May 2, the curfew for children under 14 will become 12-7 pm, where one parent is allowed to accompany them. Only one outing a day is allowed during this curfew for one hour maximum, and the outing has to take place within one km from home. In villages with less than 5000 inhabitants, these time frames don’t apply, and everyone can go out under the same conditions between 6am and 11pm.

description: Spain on May 3 announces that starting from May 4 the, athletes may carry out training individually, in open air spaces, twice a day, between 6:00 and 10:00 and between 20:00 and 23:00, within the limits of the municipal area in which they have their residence. They will also be able to access the natural spaces that they require. However, these restrictions do not apply to elite athletes "designated as “high-performance” by the Superior Council for Sports."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 28, the Prime Minister of Spain announced that, beginning May 4, the nation would enter a gradual de-escalation period for the country's strict lockdown. As the de-escalation will take place "at a different, yet coordinated, rate" in each province, the severity of curfew restrictions per province largely depends on that particular environment, meaning the beginning of this plan therefore replaces the national curfew restrictions preceding it. (Additionally, due to the province-centric characteristic of the de-escalation measure, all advancements in the plan will be coded sub-nationally for each individual province.)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On May 3, the Government of Spain announces that, with the start of Phase 0 on May 4, athletes not "designated as “high-performance” by the Superior Council for Sports" but still "affiliated with clubs may train individually in the open air between 6am and 10am."

*As the 4-phase deescalation plan is asynchronous for each national region, whenever Andalusia enters a phase, it's effects will be coded sub- nationally.
type_sub_cat: No the curfew times are always the same regardless of the day of the week
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: On May 4, Andalusia enters Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de escalation plan. Furthermore, the previously instilled curfew mandating that children under 14 are allowed outside for a single one hour each day between 12 pm- 7 pm and within one km from home is now included in this Phase 0. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de escalation plan, this curfew is now viewed as a sub-national policy, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well Andalusia handles its virus environment.

description: On May 4, The Valencian Community enters Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de escalation plan. Furthermore, the previously installed curfew that allows people 14 or older (but less than 70/ not dependent) to exercise outside (on a bike within one's city or a one-hour walk within 0.5 miles of one's home) between 6 a.m. to 10 a.m. is now included in this Phase 0. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de-escalation plan, this curfew is now viewed as a sub-national policy, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well where the Valencian Community handles its virus environment.

description: During Phase 0 (starting May 4, 2020) in Extremadura, Spain announced a curfew policy aimed at athletes. "Other athletes affiliated with clubs," and not designated as “high-performance” by the Superior Council for Sports,  "may train individually in the open air twice a day between 6am and 10am [and another designated time slot], within the city limits of their own place of residence. These individuals may also access any natural areas that are required for their training."

description:
The Spanish Prime Minister announces on April 25 that, starting from May 2, people who need special attention/a caregiver and people aged 70+ can go out between 10-12 am accompanied by one person. The outing has to take place within one km from home, with a distance of 2m from other people. This time slot is in tandem with the 7-8 pm, with both acting as viable options for outside activity under this demographic. In villages with less than 5000 inhabitants the different time frames don’t apply, everyone can go out under the same conditions between 6am and 11pm.

 UPDATE: On May 4, Spain enters a gradual, asymmetric deescalation plan.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 25, the Prime Minister of Spain announces that, starting May 2, people 14 or older (but less than 70/ not dependent) can take one-hour walks, accompanied by one person, once a day within half a mile of their homes, or do sports like riding a bike alone within their city. The timeframe set for this activity is between 6 a.m. to 10 a.m. (or 8 p.m. to 11 p.m.). UPDATE: On May 4, Spain enters a gradual, asymmetric deescalation plan.

description:
On April 28, the Prime Minister of Spain announced that, beginning May 4, the nation would enter a gradual de-escalation period for the country's strict lockdown. As the de-escalation will take place "at a different, yet coordinated, rate" in each province, the severity of curfew restrictions per province largely depends on that particular environment, meaning the beginning of this plan therefore replaces the national curfew restrictions preceding it. (Additionally, due to the province-centric characteristic of the de-escalation measure, all advancements in the plan will be coded sub-nationally for each individual province.)

 UPDATE: On June 21, the national state of alarm is lifted therefore ending the de-escalation plan.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
A curfew is implemented for people at night between 20:00 and 06:00 throughout the territory of the Valencian Community, unless any of the following activities are being carried out:
a)	Procurement of medicines, medical devices or other goods 
of first necessity.
b)	Assistance to health centers, services or establishments.
c)	Assistance to veterinary care centers for reasons of urgency
d)	Fulfillment of labor, professional, business obligations (institutional or legal).
e)	Return to the place of habitual residence.
f)	Assistance and care for the elderly, minors, dependents, people 
with disabilities or particularly vulnerable persons.
g)	Development of hunting activities linked to the control of the overabundance of hunting species that may cause damage to ecosystems.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On March 13, 2020, the national Government of Spain has declared a state of emergency throughout the national territory for a period of fifteen days, to face the health emergency situation caused by the COVID-19 coronavirus in Spain. The declaration of the State of Alarm affects the entire national territory for 15 days, which may be extended with the authorization of the Congress of Deputies if necessary. This means that as of today, the competent authority in the entire territory will be the Government of Spain. The Royal Decree will come into force with immediate effect, as it will be published in the Official State Gazette tonight. 

The government of the province of Aragon announced on March 14, 2020 that it would follow the state of emergency put in place by the national government by adopting coordinated measures to effectively influence the evolution of the contagion curve in Aragon and in the country as a whole.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:

The duration of the state of alarm is fifteen calendar days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

"Firefighters and military staff will now be authorised to transport corpses where necessary, while residents who have escaped infection will be given the option to move to nearby hotels or family homes."
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description: Spain is extending the emergency state until April 26. It was voted by the Congress on April 09. UPDATE: The state of emergency was extended until April 26 on April 09

description:
Regional government of Castilla and León has drawn up the ‘Plan of prevention and control measures to deal with the health crisis caused by COVID-19 after the expiration of the term of the Alarm State’, that was approved on June 19 by the extraordinary Government Council.

This Agreement was published on June 20 in the Official Gazette of the Community and entered into force on June 21.

description: The Spanish government has ordered a 15-day state of emergency to bring down Covid-19 infection rates in the capital, after a court in Madrid overturned a partial lockdown imposed earlier. This state of emergency will result in restrictions on mass gatherings, businesses, and movement between other cities.

description: "Spain declares a state of alarm to contain the spread of infections caused by SARSCoV-2 through the Royal Decree 926/2020 of the 25th of October, 2020. The competent authority will be the Government of the Nation. In each autonomous community and city with a Statute of Autonomy,  the competent authority will be the one who holds the presidency of the autonomous community. These authorities will be responsible for dictating the orders, resolutions and provisions for the application of the provisions in relation to: nighttime curfews , limitation of the permanence of groups of people in public spaces including worship places, suspension of limitations, among others. It is established that the measure will be in place until the 9th of November, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Spain declares the state of alarm to contain the spread of infections caused by SARS-CoV-2 through Royal Decree 926/2020 of October 25, 2020. In each autonomous community and city with a Statute of Autonomy, the delegated competent authority will be the one who holds up the presidency of the Autonomous Community or city with a Statute of Autonomy. These authorities will be responsible for issuing orders, resolutions, and provisions in the following areas: curfews, Limitation of entry and exit in the autonomous communities and cities with the Statute of Autonomy, limitation in the permanence of groups of people in public and private spaces and places of worship, between others. This royal decree should be held up until the 9th of November, 2020
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 14, the town of Zahara de la Sierra in Andalucia, Spain "cut itself off from the outside world, " blocking "all but one of the town's five entrances." description:
On March 22, the Government of Spain announced that, starting March 23, entry for travelers "originating in countries from outside the Schengen area" will be restricted at air and sea ports for at least the next 30 days. Exceptions to this rule are:

a) Residents of the European Union or Schengen associated countries, who are heading directly to their place of residence.

b) Holders of a long-term visa issued by a Member State or Schengen associated country heading to the latter.

c) Cross-border workers.

d) Healthcare professionals or those who look after the elderly travelling to exercise their profession.

e) Personnel engaged in the transport of goods in the exercise of their profession and the necessary flight crew to perform commercial air transport activities.

f) Diplomatic and consular staff, personnel working for international organisations, the armed forces and members of humanitarian organisations in the exercise of their duties.

g) People travelling on duly accredited imperative family grounds.

h) People that can provide documentary accreditation of grounds of force majeure or situations of need, or whose entry is permitted on humanitarian grounds.

i) Spaniards and residents of Spain

(This policy exists on top of the still present cruise ship ban).

Exemptions to this border close include "Spanish nationals, Spanish residents returning to their homes in Spain, ‘cross-border’ workers or those with special authorisation will be allowed to enter Spain."

description: On March 25, the Government of Spain introduces looser restrictions in regards to travel from Italy to Spain. The goal of these looser restrictions is to allow the transport of Spanish citizens who were trapped in Italy due to the March 10 travel ban. The rest of the restrictions from the original March 10 travel ban still hold.

description:
On May 12, the Spanish Government announced that, starting midnight on May 15, "entry into national territory at internal borders at ports and airports (for ships and planes originating in countries in the Schengen area)" will be restricted for at least 30 days, with exceptions to these border controls being: 
1. Spanish citizens.
2. Residents in Spain, accrediting their primary residence.
3. Cross-border workers.
4. Healthcare professionals or those who look after the elderly to exercise their labour activity.
5. Those people who can show documentary evidence of causes of force majeure or a situation of need.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description: On March 25, the Government of Spain introduces looser restrictions in regards to travel from Italy to Spain. The goal of these looser restrictions is to allow the transport of Spanish citizens who were trapped in Italy due to the March 10 travel ban. The rest of the restrictions from the original March 10 travel ban still hold. UPDATE: On May 19, the Government of Spain lifts the "ban on all direct flights and ships from Italy" that had been in place since March 10. However, tourism and cruise ships are still restricted.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Non-essential workers (please note their occupation in the text entry where applicable)

description: On March 12, the Government of Spain announced that, beginning midnight March 13, cruise ships would be banned from entering the country. This measure would be effective at least until March 27, with the possibility of extension. UPDATE: After being extended twice since its original March 13 introduction, on June 16, the Spanish Ministry of Transport announces that the restrictions will be extended to "foreign registered vessels and recreational boats unless manned by a professional crew and registered with an official board." Additionally, the overall ban is extended indefinitely.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On June 14, the Government of Spain announced that, starting June 21, the country will reopen its borders (ports and airports) with all European Union and Schengen-area countries (including the UK).
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
target_region: European Union (with the UK),Schengen Area (with the UK)

description: Starting June 21, the only EU/Schengen Area nation that Spain continues to impose land border restrictions with is Portugal, with the same exemptions to this rule applying as they did with the original March 17 border resections. This will continue until July 1, when both countries agreed to reopen their land borders.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 4, the Government of Spain effectively reopens the countries external borders to a list of 12 countries recommended by the EU: Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Montenegro, New Zealand, Rwanda, Serbia, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia and Uruguay (Cruise ships are still banned indefinitely, however). Additionally, the country is considering reopening the passage of citizens from Morocco, Algeria and China if there is reciprocity on the part of these nations and there is a permitted flow in the opposite direction. Finally, when regarding the rest of the world still restricted from entry, "some additional categories [for exemptions to the restriction] have been [introduced,] ... [with] the scope of [some exemptions already present] ...  [being] extended."
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Effective February 1, 2022, U.S. citizens can travel from the United States to Spain on non-essential travel (such as tourism) if they show proof that they are fully vaccinated and have received the last required dose of their COVID-19 vaccine no less than 14 days, and no more than 270 days (9 months), prior to arrival in Spain. If more than 270 days (9 months) have passed since receiving the last required dose of their COVID-19 vaccine, U.S. citizens must show proof of having received a booster shot at least 14 days prior to arrival in Spain.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People who are partially vaccinated against COVID-19,People who are not vaccinated against COVID-19,People who are neither vaccinated nor recovered from COVID-19

description:
On March 15, the Government of Spain announced that, within the next 3 days, "autonomous communities must notify the Ministry of Health...  all the provisions and containment measures that the.. . competent authorities of the autonomous communities and local entities have adopted on the occasion of the coronavirus" up until March 14. These communicated measures include:
a) Limitations on the freedom of movement of people.
b) Establishments, equipment and activities whose opening to the public is
would have suspended or conditioned.
c) Ensuring the supply of products necessary for the protection of
public health.

description: On March 15, the Government of Spain imposes a policy stating that the "autonomous communities [of the country] must send the... Ministry of Health [information on the local] epidemiological situation, the situation of... healthcare capacity[,] and the needs for... [human and material] resources." UPDATE: On April 17, the Government of Spain imposes a modification on the March 15 order revolving around communication between the autonomous communities and the Ministry of Health. The point of this modification in the order is to adapt "to the evolution of the health crisis." Some of the modifications to the policy include an expansion of "the information related to the hiring of human resources," as well as a mandate that autonomous communities must now separate reports of symptomatic cases from asymptomatic cases.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Spain has introduced a de-escalation period on 4 May 2020 to guide the country back to "nueva normalidad" (new normality). This period ended on 21 June 2020.
It consists of four phases: 0 - preparation, 1 - initial phase, 2 - intermediate phase, 3 - advanced phase. Each region will progress to the next phase depending on strategic capacities of the healthcare system, the epidemiologic situation, the compliance with public protection measures and data on mobility and socio-economic details. The time to stay within each phase was initially set to 2 weeks for each province, but this was not always met in reality.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On May 11, the "Ministry of Health [promotes]... a ministerial order that regulates the obligations and procedures for obtaining and communicating information for epidemiological surveillance related to COVID-19 during the transition phase towards a new normal." Essentially, this order sees the creation of a more relevant information collection system than before, and mandates specific ways of receiving data that are designed to facilitate the transition to a new normality. Several of these mandates are:

1. "The order obliges all health and social health centers, services and establishments, both in the public and private sectors, as well as the health professionals who work in them, to provide all the data necessary for the monitoring and epidemiological surveillance of COVID- 19 that are required by the competent health authority. " 

2. It "is also established that the autonomous communities and cities will guarantee that a PCR test or other appropriate molecular diagnostic technique is carried out on each suspected case of COVID-19 in the first 24 hours from the knowledge of the symptoms."  

3. As "of today, the public health units of the Autonomous Communities must obtain daily data on suspected and confirmed cases from the public and private systems, as well as from the occupational risk prevention services."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective June 10th, Spain will require that "Interprovincial air and land transport operators" as well as "operators of maritime transport... with pre-allocated seating" will have to "collect contact information for all passengers and keep the lists a minimum of four weeks after the trip" in case one or more of the passengers gets Covid-19. They will also be required to "provide these lists to public health authorities when they are required, with the purpose of performing contact tracing."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Effective June 29th, Spain imposed health monitoring measures at airports and maritime ports of entry. All passengers who arrive at these points of entry will have their temperature taken with "no-contact thermometers or thermal cameras," in addition to undergoing a "visual inspection," and filling out an online "public health questionnaire" which will be presented through QR code upon entry. Tourist companies and airlines are responsible for reminding travelers about their "obligation to present the public health questionnaire at the airport or port of destination."  

"Passengers with a temperature over 37.5 ºC (99.5ºF)," or those that are "suspected to suffer from COVID-19 or another pathogen" based on the written and visual health inspections will be subjected to further health inspections to evaluate the risk they pose to public health. If suspicion of a public health hazard is confirmed, "established health crisis protocols will be activated" and the person will be taken to a "health center."

These rules will remain in effect "until the government declares an end to the health crisis caused by COVID-19."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Regional Government of Castilla and Leon published on March 11 the list of preventive measures due to rising number of COVID 19 cases in the region. One of them includes that scheduled healthcare activities in hospital healthcare facilities (consultations, examinations and interventions) may be suspended or limited.

The policy ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19. UPDATE: The original policy was supposed to end on March 26, but it actually ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 19, the Spanish Minister of Health, Salvador Illa, reports the addition of more than 50,000 medical and nursing personnel to Spains "human health team" against Covid-19. description: On March 29, 2020. The regional president, Alfonso Fernández Mañueco, announced today that the Junta de Castilla y León has managed to bring in five more planes with health protection material since the first one arrived last Tuesday with six tonnes of health material from China. Specifically, over the weekend and until tomorrow, Monday, a total of five planes will arrive at the airports of Barcelona, Zaragoza and Madrid with a total load of more than one million units of health protection material, including masks, waterproof gowns, gloves, face shields and overalls, among others.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 30, 2020. New planes continue to arrive at different airports with protective equipment for health and social workers and other essential services personnel contracted by the Junta de Castilla y León to prevent and fight against the coronavirus. Since last Saturday, 28th March, until today, Monday 30th, four planes have arrived from China to supply the needs of protection material for the staff of hospitals, health centres, socio-health and emergency services of the Community. One more will arrive this afternoon-evening at Zaragoza airport with material for Castilla y León. Among all the material purchased are masks, waterproof gowns, gloves, face shields and overalls, among others. This shipment consists of a total of 106,800 waterproof gowns.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

It will be launched with about 600 health professionals, including doctors, nurses, assistants and orderlies.

description: On April 03, 2020. The Junta de Castilla y León will receive four flights from China today that will provide new protection material for health and social services personnel. The first three flights have arrived early in the morning at the airports of Madrid and Zaragoza, and a fourth will arrive in the afternoon to Madrid. In total, 1,513,708 masks, 64,260 waterproof gowns, 965,000 gloves, 120,000 goggles, 4,000 divers and 1,000 face shields will be received today. All the material received is immediately distributed to the nine provinces according to the needs of health centres, nursing homes and other social centres.

description: On April 04, 2020. The first 35 ventilators for intensive care acquired by the Junta de Castilla y León on March 12 in the United States have arrived today in Valladolid from Amsterdam, with the idea of distributing them immediately by the hospitals of Sacyl according to the current needs of each one. Ventilators are standard for ventilating all types of patients in different intensive care settings, and are manufactured in the United States. The Ministry of Health is waiting for the 65 missing teams to arrive in the coming days.

description: On April 06, 2020. Today a new flight has arrived at Madrid airport from China that carried 68,720 waterproof gowns, 970,000 gloves and 20,000 protective glasses acquired by the Junta de Castilla y León. This material is in addition to the 8.8 million protective items distributed among health centers, social services, pharmacies and agri-food companies to deal with the coronavirus. In total, more than 3.1 million surgical masks, 764,000 FFP2, 12,000 FFP3, 3.8 million gloves, 369,000 gowns, 41,800 divers, 82,000 glasses, 78,000 protective screens, 409,000 socks, 31,800 hoods, 26,300 hydroalcoholic gels, 1,200 pajamas and 22,000 swabs have already been distributed.

description: On April 10, 2020. The Junta de Castilla y León maintains its logistics and transport structure at full capacity during this festive period, and distributes daily more than one million units of health material and equipment among hospitals, primary care centers, territorial delegations and socio-health centers. More than 10 trailer trucks carry the material from the airport to the logistics center, where between 15 and 20 people perform the tasks of entry, classification and distribution, to which we must add the provincial distribution devices once the merchandise arrives.

description: The Government of Spain will distribute 238,000 masks in Extremadura starting April 13, 2020. 60% of the distribution will take place in urban areas and 40% will take place in rural areas. "The masks will be distributed at train and bus stations; at urban bus stops; at entrances and exits of industrial estates; places where the activity of the construction sector returns, as well as in access to cities and county seats," especially taking "the prevalence of small businesses in rural municipalities" into account. Distribution will be "carried out by the Security Forces and Bodies: Civil Guard through all its companies, the National Police from its police stations and volunteers from Civil Protection and the Red Cross."
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 13, 2020. The president wanted to thank the effort of the researchers of Castilla y León who have presented themselves to the call for aid for proposals and research projects on Covid-19, launched by the Carlos III Health Institute. A total of 17 projects from the universities and research centers of Castilla y León have been submitted to this call. Fernández Mañueco has anticipated that the Board will finance the projects presented by teams of the Community that are of interest, coordinating these actions with those of the Carlos III Institute. Thus, some 2.4 million euros will be allocated to support these researchers, which represents 10% of what the Institute has put for this call. The Ministry of Education is currently studying whether these funds will be used to co-finance the projects submitted to this call or if those that are not selected, but that the Institute itself considers to have sufficient relevance, will be financed. The objective is for Castilla y León to continue contributing to the fight against COVID-19, with one of its strengths: its universities and researchers. And this support will be carried out by joining forces and working together with other entities and institutions, such as the Ministry of Science and Innovation or the CSIC.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Spain on March 19 establishes that hygienic face masks must be labelled with the following information: the company data; product denomination; container content; composition; recommended period of use; essential features including size if relevant; manufacturing batch; place of origin; health warnings; recommendations for use, placement and maintenance; Technical specifications; bacterial filtration efficiency and breathability and final price. Additionally, unit-sale of face masks is only allowed in pharmacies. This is part of a set of measurements to ensure that citizens can access hygienic preventive products in informed and economic conditions.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On April 23, 2020. This morning a plane from Shanghai has arrived at the Madrid airport with sanitary material -test, divers and protective gowns-, which the Regional Health Management (Sacyl) has bought from the company Zuhai Livzon Diagnostics Inc. This acquisition represents a total of 125,000 igG/IgM rapid tests, and is one of the first deliveries to arrive in Castilla y León. Next week the arrival of another 125,000 tests is expected and there will be more on successive dates. These tests will be distributed throughout all the health areas of the Community and will be used to check the presence or not of Covid-19 antibodies in patients of the Primary Care and Hospital Care services, health professionals and workers and users of the socio-sanitary residences. The tests will gradually reach all the aforementioned groups.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Spain establishes a maximum sale price of surgical masks to the public of 0,96€, hand sanitisers and gels, depending on the amount purchased shall cost between 0,015€ and 0,021€ per millilitre, starting from April 24. This is part of a set of measurements to ensure that citizens are able to access health protection products under economic conditions.

description: On April 25, 2020. The Ministry of Development and Environment, through the Civil Protection Agency of Castilla y León, continues its work to guarantee the safety of the essential and complementary services of the citizen protection system, and for this purpose yesterday supplied various material and personal protection equipment to the Local Police of Salamanca, Ponferrada and Laguna de Duero. This delivery is added to those already made previously to twenty-eight Local Police Forces of the Autonomous Community, which have been provided since the declaration of the state of alarm until yesterday more than 12,000 masks, 10,400 gloves, more than 100 liters of hydroalcoholic gel and 28 liters of disinfection liquid.

description:
Spain distribute 10 million Masks throughout Spain to the workers who return to their professional activity between April 12 and April 13

UPDATE
The Government will distribute 6 million masks from Monday onwards in the transport hubs. The delegations and sub-delegations of the Spanish Government have received during this weekend 14.5 million masks, of which 6 million will be distributed in the transport nodes, 7 million to the city councils and the remaining 1.5 million to social entities in the territories, as reported by the Ministry of Territorial Policy and Public Function. 
 UPDATE: In line with the new transport policy which makes masks obligatory the government will distribute 6 million masks in transport hubs.

description: On May 15, the Spanish Ministry of Health announces that the process of choosing applicants for "specialized training of the different health professions" will take place through "electronic means" this year. Additionally, the number of applicants that will be accepted will be increased by 193 places spread throughout the different medical professions (i.e. Medicine, nursing, biology, chemistry, psychology, physics, and pharmacy). These changes will allow for "a reinforcement of the current staff of health centers."

description: On May 18, the Spanish Ministry of Health establishes "a technical document on 'Recommendations for scheduling surgery in safe conditions during the transition period of the COVID-19 pandemic' whose objective is to serve as a guide to hospitals to develop their local protocols in order to reintroduce programmed surgical activity." The document stresses a "a safe and staggered" reintroduction of surgeries and the protecting of professionals, and "indicates that it is important to continuously evaluate the epidemiological conditions of the population where the hospital is located."

description: On May 24, the Spanish Ministry of Health releases recommendations on "the opening to the public of beaches and bathing areas." In this recommendation document, it is urged for "extreme measures of social distancing and hygiene on the beaches" to be followed. Additionally, it "is recommended to clean and disinfect the different facilities such as the railings, the access steps to the water and the showers, as well as the sun loungers, umbrellas, seats, wastebaskets and, in general, urban furniture and recreational facilities." Other recommendations also include insisting "on the need for collective awareness in respect of social distancing" and the advice to avoid "gatherings of more than 15 people."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On June 10, the Spanish Ministry of Health, in collaboration with Spanish universities, releases a "document recommending prevention and hygiene against COVID-19" in order to "publicize the technical and operational information on the measures to be taken during face-to-face teaching activity in university centers for the 2020-2021 academic year." These recommendations include the use of masks and the creation of an "action procedure" in the case off symptoms being displayed by "any person in the university center."

description:
On June 22, the Government of Spain publishes a "guide with recommendations on the use and maintenance of air conditioning and ventilation systems in buildings and commercial premises." "The document establishes a series of technical criteria to protect public health, with the aim of preventing the spread of COVID-19 in public spaces and premises with mechanical ventilation or air conditioning, such as offices, shopping centers, sports or cultural facilities, among others." Such recommendations include the following:

1. "The guide emphasizes that air renewal is the most important parameter. If possible, a minimum of 12.5 liters [of air] per second (l / s) per occupant is recommended." "To ensure this minimum value," the guide explains that one can either "increase ventilation or reduce the occupation of spaces."

2. The guide emphasizes verifying "that the equipment in charge of air renewal works, at least, in their nominal design conditions and that the possible pressure losses, especially internal to the system, are minimal."

3. The guide recommends "eliminating or reducing air recirculation whenever operating conditions allow it."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On June 8, 2020, The Catalan Ministry of Health announced it is is finalizing arrangements to make compensation payments to health professionals. A plan to support the primary care system will also be launched. The initial investment will be €4.5m, and 436 professionals will be hired in the coming months.

During the pandemic, 3,527 professionals were hired from outside the health system. A commitment has also been made to hire around half of the residents who worked through to the end of May.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
Castilla and Leon (Spain) - Government of Castilla and Leon allocates 20 million euros from the “Emergency COVID 19 Fund” to help provincial governments and city councils that have more than 20,000 inhabits to pay for the expenses generated in social services. July 30, 2020. 

- three million euros to reinforce the care files for dependency and other basic needs (15% of the total fund)
- strengthening of proximity services, such as remote health support, home help, such as program "Crecemos y Conciliamos", to which 3 million euros are allocated (15% of the total fund)
- expenses necessary to cover the needs in the retirement centers for the elderly and people with disabilities: they will serve to reinforce the workforce through new hires or replacements; acquire Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and diagnostic tests for employees and users; finance disinfection measures for facilities and improve safety by distributing spaces and routes to avoid contagion; and carry out small works and the acquisition of equipment for the sectorization or application of contingency plans against COVID-19. 7 million euros (35 percent of the total amount of the extraordinary fund) are allocated for this purpose.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: Other population not specifed above,No special population targeted

description:
The Department of Work, Social Affairs and Families has launched a plan to care for people who use nursing homes in the Girona area who have mild symptoms of Covidien-19. The regions of Girona have as of today a new resource in Girona to attend to the mild cases of people who are in residences who cannot guarantee adequate isolation of the users or have a lack of personnel. With this initiative, it will be possible to sponge the residential centers that need it and guarantee good customer service.

The new service has 147 places and, for now, it already welcomes 10 users of a residence in Sant Hilari.

description:
On March 17, the "Spanish Agency for Medicines and Health Products (AEMPS)" establishes "a series of exceptional measures to manage the development of clinical trials during the period of health crisis due to the coronavirus ( COVID-19)." Additionally, these "measures are not specific to clinical trials for the treatment of coronavirus, but affect all clinical trials," and "have the objective of allowing these trials to continue [while also] guaranteeing the safety and well-being of the patients, preserving their validity and avoiding an overload of care in... [health] centers. These measures include:

1. Those responsible for the clinical trial can postpone face-to-face visits or transform them into telephone visits, depending on the characteristics of each trial.

2. Those responsible for the clinical trial can interrupt the recruitment and even the treatment of patients to avoid unnecessary risks and ensure healthcare. 

3. Transfer of patients from one center to another.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Catalan Government promotes the ORFEU Program on April 7, 2020. It is a massive population testing program to detect Covid-19, which will start with 170,000 tests over six weeks, with the possibility of increasing the volume and which will cost 1.38 million euros.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 14, the Spanish Ministry of Health promotes a "a ministerial order that makes public and private clinical diagnostic laboratories available to the autonomous communities." According to the order, all "centers, services and health establishments that are not providing service in the National Health System, as well as their personnel, will be at the service of the CCAA." In addition to setting "exceptional measures to strengthen the National Health System and contain the health crisis," the order also  "sets the requirements for carrying out diagnostic tests for the detection of COVID-19," stating that "tests must be prescribed by a physician in accordance with the guidelines, instructions and criteria agreed upon by the competent health authority." Finally, the order requires centers to notify the CCAA of "confirmed COVID-19 cases," leaves the door ajar for regulations on the price of testing, and mandates "that public or private entities that acquire material for diagnostic tests" inform "the competent health authority of the autonomous community in which they are located... the type of material, number of units purchased and destination of use" for such resources.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Catalonia, April 28, 2020 the Government today approved the activation of phase 2 of the Covid-19 Mass Detection Program based on the PCR capacity of the agents of the Catalan knowledge system (Orfeo Program), with the incorporation of new university laboratories (allows adding the specialized facilities of the University of Barcelona (UB), Pompeu Fabra University (UPF), Autonomous University of Barcelona (UAB), Rovira i Virgili University (URV) to the Covid-19 mass detection initiative and Eureca (through the Omics Science Center, COS). This extension of the Orfeo program means adding capacity to carry out 139,000 tests, in addition to the 170,000 planned in the first phase, in a period of about six weeks and a new investment of 1.2 million euros.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Since August 15, 2020, Barcelona has signed up to the Department of Health's strategy of hunting down covid-19. The Catalan capital has launched this Saturday the massive screening in Torre Baró, the neighborhood with the highest circulation of the virus: the accumulated incidence in the last 15 days in the neighborhood is 573 cases per 100,000 inhabitants, almost three times more than the average of the Catalan capital. The objective of the massive tests, which will be carried out this weekend at a rate of 400 daily, is to detect asymptomatic cases that infect without knowing it and to stop the transmission chains

description: On March 19, 2020, the Catalan Government indicates that the following measure will enter into force on March 25, 2020. During the duration of the alarm and health emergency period, health waste generated in hospitals and health centers from the activity care in patients diagnosed or suspected of suffering from Covid19, and who are considered risky waste, Group III, will be segregated and managed as follows: a) Sharp, sharp waste, containing biological fluids and secretions, are they must be collected in 30 and 60-liter containers and duly accredited needles. b) The rest of the waste from health care to these patients, such as PPE equipment, care materials, gauze, probes, empty serum bags, tubing, and others, must be collected in a double gauge bag 220, capacity up to 240 liters and with secure closure.

description: Spain announces on May 3 that starting from May 4, the wearing of face masks is compulsory in all types of public transport. In case people are not living in the same household but sitting in the same vehicle, they also have to wear the masks in private cars.

Spain announces on May 3 that starting from May 4, businesses must comply with special hygiene measures: if clothing or footwear are sold, each garment, as well as the testers, must be disinfected after each use. A disinfection of the premises will be necessary twice a day, one of them, at its closure. And employee uniforms will have to be washed daily with water over 60 degrees. Customers may not use the toilets except in cases of need. If a safety distance of two meters is not possible, masks will be mandatory. All businesses must make hydroalcoholic gels available to their customers.

description: On May 14, the Ministry of Health establishes "basic security measures to ensure the health of citizens in swimming pools." Additionally, this safety protocol "will come into force only and exclusively when the Transition Plan towards a new normality establishes that the opening is possible." These measures include "the ventilation of closed spaces, such as changing rooms and bathrooms;" "the disinfection of all the furniture;"maintaining "the treatment and residual disinfection levels in the water; " "[c]apacity and access control," and the creation of"systems for hand [and shoe] disinfection at the entrance" of the facility.

description:
In all public places, the person or entity that owns the economic activity or, where appropriate, the director, director or person in charge of the centers, facilities, spaces for public use and entities, must ensure that the cleaning and disinfection measures appropriate to the characteristics and intensity of use of the establishments, premises, facilities or spaces listed below are adopted. In the cleaning and disinfection tasks, special attention will be paid to the areas of common use and to the most frequent contact surfaces such as doorknobs, tables, furniture, handrails, floors, telephones, hangers and other elements of similar characteristics, according to the following guidelines:
1) Disinfectants such as dilutions of freshly prepared bleach (1:50) or any of the disinfectants with virucidal activity that are on the market and duly authorized and registered will be used. In the use of that product, the indications on the label shall be respected.

description: On March 14, the Spanish government declared a state of emergency for the nation which includes internal border conditions. Under these conditions, movement between the country's provinces is restricted, only being available if one is "traveling for essential health reasons;" "traveling for essential work, professional, or business reasons;" "traveling to return to ... [one's] family residence;" "traveling ... [to provide] assistance and care of the elderly, dependent, or disabled;" or "traveling due to force majeure or a situation of need."

description:
In accordance with the primary lockdown measure, on March 14 Spain implements a ban on traveling on public roads unless for the several activities deemed essential as clarified in the aforementioned measure ("To buy essentials from supermarkets or pharmacies," "To go to work," etc.) To maintain compliance, police will install "'fixed and mobile' police checkpoints on roads, in public areas and on public transport," where violators can be "slapped with fines starting at €100 for disobeying the conditions of the state of alert, or [can even face prison time] ... should they 'resist or seriously disobey the authorities or officers when they are carrying out their functions.'" Additionally, only one individual may drive in a car at a time, except when justified ("in the case of people with mobility difficulties," for example), in which case the passenger "sits at the back and on the opposite side from the driver."
 

.

description: On March 17, the Government of Spain announces that, starting March 18, “landing in all airports in the [Canary or Balearic] Islands for executive aviation flights, air taxi or operations similar to these, regardless of their origin” is prohibited. Additionally, these restrictions apply to maritime transportation as well, as now “disembarkation is prohibited in the ports located in the territory of the Autonomous Community of the Canary Islands for passengers embarked on ro-ro passenger ships and passenger ships that provide regular line service, with passage on board, originating in the peninsula,” with these same measures applying to the ports of "Palma, Alcúdia, Maó, Ciutadella and Eivissa" of the Balearic Islands.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 17, the Government of Spain announces that, starting March 19, “it is prohibited to carry out any type of commercial or private flight, originating from any airport located in the national territory and destination any airport located in the territory of
Canary Islands,” as well as it is “prohibited to carry out any type of commercial or private flight, from any airport located in the national territory and the airports located in the territory of the Balearic Islands.”
These restrictions also carry over to sea ports, where "entry into all the ports of the [Canary or Balearic] Islands of all vessels and pleasure boats used for recreational or sports purposes or in nautical lease (charter), regardless of its origin” is prohibited.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: As announced April 28, on May 4, the National Government of Spain begins a "de-escalation" plan to lift lockdown restrictions. The beginning of this plan replaces the universal internal border restrictions with asynchronous restrictions more relevant to where each province is at in terms of Covid-19.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 14, the Spanish government declared a state of emergency for the nation which includes internal border conditions. Under these conditions, movement between the country's provinces is restricted, only being available if one is "traveling for essential health reasons;" "traveling for essential work, professional, or business reasons;" "traveling to return to ... [one's] family residence;" "traveling ... [to provide] assistance and care of the elderly, dependent, or disabled;" or "traveling due to force majeure or a situation of need." UPDATE: On May 4, the National Government of Spain replaces the overarching lockdown (and therefore internal border restrictions) with a 4-phase de-escalation framework that will move asynchronously throughout each province. This means the national internal border restrictions will be replaced by restrictions more relevant to where each province is in Covid-19 resiliance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
In accordance with the primary lockdown measure, on March 14 Spain implements a ban on traveling on public roads unless for the several activities deemed essential as clarified in the aforementioned measure ("To buy essentials from supermarkets or pharmacies," "To go to work," etc.) To maintain compliance, police will install "'fixed and mobile' police checkpoints on roads, in public areas and on public transport," where violators can be "slapped with fines starting at €100 for disobeying the conditions of the state of alert, or [can even face prison time] ... should they 'resist or seriously disobey the authorities or officers when they are carrying out their functions.'" Additionally, only one individual may drive in a car at a time, except when justified ("in the case of people with mobility difficulties," for example), in which case the passenger "sits at the back and on the opposite side from the driver."
 

. UPDATE: On May 4, the gradual, asymmetric deescalation plan begins, which creates a national/subnational hybrid policy environment, therefore replacing all national policies before it.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Autonomous of the Basque Country are maintained until the 23rd of December, 2020. It is determined that, between December 23 and 26, 2020, and between December 30, 2020, and January 2, 2021, limitations for exiting and entering the Autonomous Community of Euskadi are lifted. description:
Government of Castilla and Leon published an order on March 13 where the visits to residential centers for public and private senior citizens are suspended, except in individual circumstances in which additional care and humanization measures are applied, to be adopted by the center's management. Moreover, users are forbidden to leave their residence. 

The original policy was supposed to end on March 27, but it actually ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19. UPDATE: The original policy was supposed to end on March 27, but it actually ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On March 14, the National Government of Spain announces that, starting March 15, the entire population of the country (around 47 million) will be confined to a lockdown to curb the spread of Covid-19.  Under this lockdown, "citizens can leave their homes ONLY to buy groceries and pharmaceutical products, go to the bank or hospital, ... to take care of dependents/elderly," or walk the dog. Additionally, while "on the street, they must be unaccompanied at all times, and while they can go to work, most workplaces are to be closed to the public until further notice." (Ex. "Bars, restaurants, and shops selling anything but food and other staples must shut down. All leisure and sports activities also have to close, including cinemas, theaters, swimming pools or football grounds.") This lockdown is set to be in place as long as the National State of Alarm is still active.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From March 14, the national government of Spain has put in place a curfew affecting the entirety of the country, the region of Aragon included. The population of Aragon will therefore only be able to circulate on the roads or spaces of public use to carry out the following activities, which must be carried out individually, unless accompanied by people with disabilities, minors, elderly, or by other justified reason:

a) Acquisition of food, pharmaceutical and basic necessities, as well as acquisition of other products and provision of services in accordance with the provisions of article 10.
b) Assistance to health centers, services and establishments.
c) Displacement to the workplace to carry out their work, professional or business service.
d) Return to the place of habitual residence.
e) Assistance and care for the elderly, minors, dependents, people with disabilities or especially vulnerable people.
f) Travel to financial and insurance entities.
g) Due to force majeure or situation of need.
h) Any other activity of a similar nature
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On March 28, the Government of Spain announced that, starting March 30, all nonessential activities will be halted until April 9. This means that nonessential workers who were allowed to go to work under the previous March 15 lockdown measures are now barred from doing so for 2 weeks. In terms of the mandate, all essential activities that will be allowed to continue operation include "those considered necessary for the maintenance of basic social functions (health, security, social and economic wellbeing of citizens)." Additionally, nonessential workers will still "receive their usual salaries but [will] have to make up lost hours at a later date." All other restrictions from the original lockdown procedure (March 15) are still in effect as well.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:

Additionally, while "on the street, they must be unaccompanied at all times, and while they can go to work, most workplaces are to be closed to the public until further notice." (Ex. description: On April 21,  Spain's Health Minister Salvador Illa announced that, beginning April 26, restrictions regarding outside activity for children  younger than 14 (imposed under the March 14 lockdown) will be lifted on April 26. All other restrictions imposed by the March 14 lockdown are still in place.

description: On April 25, Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez announces that, starting May 2, major restrictions involving outside activity imposed via the March 14 lockdown will be lifted. Individuals 14 or older, under 70, and non-dependent are allowed to "take one-hour walks, accompanied by one person, once a day within half a mile of their homes, or do sports like riding a bike alone within their city." Additionally, these activities are restricted to two time frames (see curfew category) and social distancing.

description: On April 28, the Prime Minister of Spain announced that, beginning May 4, the nation would enter a gradual de-escalation period for the country's strict lockdown. As the de-escalation will take place "at a different, yet coordinated, rate" in each province, the beginning of this plan replaces the national lockdown measures that preceded it (additionally, due to the province-centric characteristic of the measure, all advancements in the plan will be coded sub-nationally for each individual province.)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Spain on May 3 announces that starting from May 4, as part of Phase 0 of the 4-phase de-escalation plan, athletes qualified by the Higher Sports Council as being of a high level or of national interest, may carry out training individually, outdoors, and only in the province where they reside. They may freely access, if necessary, those natural spaces in which they must carry out their sporting activities, such as the sea, rivers, or reservoirs. Additionally, trainers are allowed to accompany athletes, and an additional person may be in attendance in the case of paralympic sports.

*As the 4-phase deescalation plan is asynchronous for each national region, whenever Andalusia enters a phase, it's effects will be coded sub- nationally.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: On May 4, Andalusia entered Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de escalation plan. Additionally, the lockdown lifting allowing “Individuals 14 or older, under 70, and non-dependent” to "take one-hour walks, accompanied by one person, once a day within half a mile of their homes, or do sports like riding a bike alone within their city" is now included in this phase 0. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de escalation plan, this loosened restriction on lockdown will now be coded subnationally, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well Andalusia handles its virus environment. (More info on the curfew side of this policy can be found in the "curfew" category.)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
