description:
Two weeks after the start of the de-escalation, Barcelona have obtained the green light to engage in the process. The Government has approved its pass to phase 1 next Monday ( May 25) along with the other great laggard, the community of Castilla y León. 
-All businesses can be opened with 30% of the capacity and as long as the premises do not exceed 400 square meters in area. 
-Meetings with family and friends may be held, as long as the groups do not exceed 10 people and taking into account the distance and hygiene measures. You can also go to the terraces, which will have to have a distance of two meters between tables, whose number may not exceed 50% compared to the previous year.

-Hotels and tourist accommodation may be opened, but common areas may not be used. 
-Libraries will be opened for lending and reading, with capacity reduced to 30%, as will museums. 
-The theater, cinema and concerts can be reactivated with a third of the capacity and less than 20 people indoors and less than 200 outdoors.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: As of June 5th, 2020, Madrid is allowed to progress to the third stage of easing the national lockdown restrictions. Timetables for outdoor exercise are lifted, while restaurants and bars are allowed to open their interiors at 40 percent capacity. Additionally, swimming pools and beaches are allowed to open under the requirements of social distancing rules and a maximum of 30 percent occupancy.

description:
In the framework of the de-escalation plan that is being carried out in Spain to try to achieve the "new normal", Barcelona will enter phase 2 as of next Monday, June 8. 
In phase 2, meetings of up to 15 people can be held. In addition, in phase 2 all the previously established time slots are eliminated, with the exception of the slot reserved for people over 70 years of age, which will be between 10:00 and 12:00 and between 19:00 and 19:00. 20:00 hour

description:
Catalonia, June 6, 2020, fourteen weeks after the closure of educational centers that preceded the confinement and after almost six weeks of dancing phases and what can and cannot be done in each one, all of Catalonia today is in phase 3, the last before recovering the normality (with conditions).

The Ministry of Health yesterday gave the green light to the change of phase in Barcelona and the metropolitan area and Lleida. The Official State Gazette (BOE) must publish today the order for this phase change, which means that all of Catalonia becomes a single territorial unit, which means that mobility restrictions between the different health regions have ended.

description:
July 2nd, 2020

Asturias, España.

Asturias government announces the resolution of the liberation of outdoor activities.

From the next day and onwards, people will be able to do outdoor activities as long as they wear a mask and social distancing of at least 1.5 meters can be assured. 

Citizens should also have no symptoms or recent contact with possitive cases.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The Valencian Community announced that people over 6 years old can only go outside - in indoors and outdoors spaces - wearing masks as long as it’s not possible to maintain the 1.5 meters of social distance.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On July 20, 2020, The Government of Catalonia announced the expansion of regulations including a mandatory stay at home order to the counties of Sant Feliu de Llobregat (Barcelona), Figueres, and Vilafant (Girona). The restrictions will last 15 days. Residents are allowed to leave their home for essential errands, such as buying medicine.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On September 25, 2020, Madrid's regional government said that beginning September 28, 2020, it would "extend restrictions on movement to another eight districts, affecting about a million people". "Residents in these areas will only be able to leave the restricted zones for essential business, such as going to school or work, or to care for dependents. Capacity at stores and other commercial establishments will be set at 50% and closing time at 10pm with the exception of pharmacies, gas stations and health centers. Bar service will be prohibited and public parks in the affected zones will also be closed"
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Extremadura, Spain's Minister of Health, José María Vergeles, announced on January 5, 2021 the "perimeter closure of the towns of Zarza la Mayor, Cabezuela del Valle, Torreorgaz, and Pueblonuevo del Guadiana" due to high infection rates. "This restriction is set to be in place for six days but may be extended."

description: On May 4, the Valencian Community enters Phase 0 of Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan. Additionally, the lockdown exemption "regarding legitimate reasons for leaving the house-" such as "to buy food, basic or pharmaceutical items; to attend medical centres; to go to and from work; [and] to look after children, older people or those with disabilities or who are especially vulnerable-" is now included in this phase. Due to the asynchronous nature of the de escalation plan, this loosened restriction will now be coded subnationally, as how long it lasts locally largely depends on how well where the Valencian Community handles its virus environment.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain on March 14 establishes a set of measurements for its internal transport: the frequency of public transport shall be reduced by at least 50%. This applies to both private and state owned road, rail, air and sea passenger transport services. If for technical or operational reasons the direct application of the percentages established from the first day is not feasible, the quickest possible adjustment of the services should be carried out, which may not last more than five days. (Article 14)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: Restriction on Frequency of Public Transport
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 19, the National Government of Spain releases an order that "establishes exceptional measures to guarantee the population's access to" resources necessary to defend against Covid-19." 

This is achieved through establishing "the procedure for setting the amount" at which "sanitary products, as well as those products necessary for the protection of [the population's]... health against COVID-19," will be sold at. Furthermore, "the pricing authority has 48 hours to set the maximum retail price" for these items [i.e. "surgical masks, nitrile gloves, hygienic masks, antiseptics, hydroalcoholic gels and solutions as well as other (medical and non-medical) devices that are considered essential to minimize the risk of COVID-19 spreading among people."]

Additionally, measures are imposed that dictate how to "determine the
information to be established on the labeling of hygienic masks" AND measures are imposed that define the conditions where a unit sale of [surgical] masks can be made to the public" when such masks are not individually packaged.
type_text: While the policy involves increasing access to health resources, it does not involve the government acquiring or distributing more resources, but instead involves the National Government of Spain increasing public access to/comprehension of these resources.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 26th, the department of employment and social policy in Basque country announced a benefit for those who can't afford to pay rent due to unemployment, reduced employment, or loss of income. Their rent can be reduced by 50%, or, depending on the severity of the situation, completely waived during the state of alarm. This benefit can also extend to up to 4 months after the state of alarm is over depending on the severity of the situation.
type_text: The policy reduces/waives rent for those struggling to pay due to effects of COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 28th, in order to help soften the financial burdens caused by COVID-19, the department of education in Basque Country announced that "in all university studies the grade necessary to access a scholarship will be reduced", "the calculation of academic performance" needed to maintain the scholarship will be more flexible, "and the administration will apply a correction coefficient to" families' "income statement if they suffer from the economic consequences of COVID-19." Additionally, "for the coming year, all university fees will be frozen and" the cost of this second semester will be reduced for those affected by COVID.
type_text: Measures to ensure university fees don't become more of a burden, especially for those who have been affected financially by COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Spain on May 3 announces that starting from May 4 four islands (La Gomera, La Graciosa, El Hierro —in the Canary Islands— and Formentera —in the Balearic Islands) enter directly into phase 1: the meeting of groups of up to 10 people will be allowed, always keeping the safety distance. Shops of less than 400 meters may open to the public without an appointment, but with a reduction in capacity to 30%. The outdoor markets can also return, with a capacity of 25% of the usual stalls and a third of the influx. In addition, the attendance capacity of the wake is expanded to 15 people.
type_text: Easing of lockdown, entering phase 1. This includes larger gatherings, opening of small shops without appointment and the return of outdoor markets.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Madrid's [Spain] emergency response services line, 112 Comunidad Madrid shared a tweet showing cars "parked in the area of La Pedriza, with forest rangers looking on. “Not like this Madrid, not like this,” the message read, accompanied by a request for people to leave the area."

In Spanish, the tweet read:
"Así no Madrid. Así no.
Es #LaPedriza a las 11:30h. Nos pasa la imagen #AgentesForestalesCM

Es necesario abandonar las áreas recreativas de la Sierra.

Por favor #quedateencasa 
#CoronavirusEspaña
#CoronavirusMadrid 
#ASEM112
#Madrid112"
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On September 8, the Ministry of Health begins "the institutional campaign #EstoNoEsUnJuego [("This is not a game")] aimed at reinforcing compliance with the protection measures against Covid-19." The objective of this campaign is "to raise awareness in society in general - with special emphasis on young people - of the importance of following the recommendations of the health authorities to avoid new infections of COVID-19." Additionally, the initiative "will be disseminated exclusively through the internet: digital media, web pages of media of different nature and scope and social networks." The campaign will end September 29.

description: As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain is enforcing a quarantine on the whole country starting March 14 for at least 15 days. "During the state of emergency, people will only be allowed out on to public streets for the following reasons: to buy food, basic or pharmaceutical items; to attend medical centres; to go to and from work; to look after children, older people or those with disabilities or who are especially vulnerable; and to attend financial or insurance offices and on force majeure ground". Private vehicles used to carry out these activities are allowed to refuel at gas stations.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Effective May 15, passengers arriving in Spain from other countries will be required to quarantine at their home/place of accommodation for the 14 days immediately following their arrival, with this mandate extending until the national state of emergency is officially lifted. During the mandatory quarantine period following your arrival in Spain, you will only be allowed to leave your home/accommodation to shop for food, medications, or other basic necessities, to seek medical assistance, or in other very limited emergency circumstances.

[for] all travellers arriving from abroad," with the quarantine's duration being tied to the state of alarm. description: Effective May 15, passengers arriving in Spain from other countries will be required to quarantine at their home/place of accommodation for the 14 days immediately following their arrival. During the mandatory quarantine period following your arrival in Spain, you will only be allowed to leave your home/accommodation to shop for food, medications, or other basic necessities, to seek medical assistance, or in other very limited emergency circumstances. This all-encompassing quarantine ended on June 21, when restrictions were lifted for "the EU, Schengen member states and a list of approved third countries." UPDATE: The original quarantine was scheduled to stay in effect as long as the national state of alarm was still recognized. This state of emergency ended on June 21, ending the broad-based quarantine by lifting the quarantine restrictions from  "the EU, Schengen member states and a list of approved third countries." However, the rest of the world still needs to abide by these restrictions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: Non-essential workers (please note their occupation in the text entry where applicable)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: On June 21, the Government Spain declared that only individuals entering the country NOT from the EU and Schengen member states (UK included) will be required to be subjected to a 14 day quarantine (with the exception of "basic activities only, such as buying necessary products or for health reasons.") Additionally, as the border with Portugal will stay closed until July 1, the quarantine exemption will apply to that country at that time.

description: Throughout the pandemic, Spain, like many other countries, accepted the WHO's recommendation for a "14-day period" of isolation as "the norm for covid." However, on September 24, the Government of Spain announces that the "mandatory quarantine for those who are close contacts of covid cases"will be reduced from "14 to 10" days. ("Anyone diagnosed with covid... must still complete the 14 day quarantine.")

The regional government of Madrid [Spain] ordered the closure of all non-essential businesses, including "cinemas, nightclubs, concert venues, theatres, gaming houses, casinos, theme parks, gyms and cocktail bars," on March 13, 2020. The order was in place until March 26.

karaoke rooms, theater cafes and concert cafes and any other recreational establishment. d) The closure of bars, cafes, restaurants and other restaurants except those that are integrated in a hotel establishment or in residential health or social centers. e) The closure of gambling establishments (recreation halls, casinos, bingo and any other). f) The closure of amusement parks, theme parks and any other center that carries out leisure or leisure activities.
recreation. This measure will enter into force on the 13th of March 2020

description: On March 12, the Castilla y Leon Community informed a) the closure of cultural centers, museums, theaters, libraries and cinemas. b) The closure of nightclubs, pubs and any other recreational establishment. c) The closure of bars, cafes, restaurants. e) The closure of gambling establishments (e.g. casinos). f) The closure of amusement parks, theme parks and any other center that carries out leisure. g) The closure of gyms, pools and any other sport centers. This measure will enter into force on the 13th of March 2020 and it will initially last 15 days.

description:
RESOLUTION SLT / 737/2020, of March 13, which adopts complementary measures for the prevention and control of SARS-CoV-2 infection. 
Closure of establishments for sports, leisure and commercial activities. The closure of shopping centers, including department stores and galleries, with the exception of those establishments dedicated exclusively to the sale of products for regular consumption (food, cleaning and hygiene) and those areas of the shopping centers with the same activity.

description: As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain on March 14 suspends the opening to the public of retail establishments with the exception of retail commercial establishments for food, beverages, products and basic necessities, pharmaceutical establishments, medical, optical and orthopedic products, hygienic products, hairdressing salons, newspapers and stationery, automotive fuel, tobacconists, technological and telecommunications equipment, pet food, internet commerce, telephone or correspondence, dry cleaners and laundries. Any other activity or establishment that in the opinion of the competent authority may pose a risk of contagion is suspended.

institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down

description: On March 14, the Andalucian Government announced the closure of bars, restaurants, beaches and non-essential businesses as a countermeasure against Covid-19 UPDATE: Later on, in the evening of March 14, the National Government of Spain announces its own national lockdown to combat the coronavirus. These measures thereby replace the ones introduced by Andalucia the same day.

description:
On March 12, the Castilla y Leon Community informed a) the closure of cultural centers, museums, theaters, libraries and cinemas. b) The closure of nightclubs, pubs and any other recreational establishment. c) The closure of bars, cafes, restaurants. e) The closure of gambling establishments (e.g. casinos). f) The closure of amusement parks, theme parks and any other center that carries out leisure. g) The closure of gyms, pools and any other sport centers. This measure will enter into force on the 13th of March 2020 and it will initially last 15 days.

 UPDATE: On March 14, the National Government of Spain announces a nationwide state of emergency. Due to this, all non-essential businesses are forced to close under a national government mandate. This new national mandate replaces the previous where the Castilla y Leon mandated the closure of businesses.

description:
From March 15, the government of Aragon suspended all retail commercial activities throughout the province's territory, except retail commercial establishments for food and basic necessities and products such as ; 

-Retail trade in non-specialized establishments
-Retail trade in non-specialized establishments, with a predominance of food products, beverages and tobacco.
- Retail sale of information and communication technology equipment in specialized stores.
-Retail sale of newspapers and stationery in specialized stores
-Retail sale of other items in specialized stores.
-Retail sale of pharmaceutical products in specialized stores
-Retail sale of medical and orthopedic articles in specialized stores.
-Retail sale of cosmetic and hygiene products in specialized stores.
-Retail trade not carried out in establishments, stalls or markets.
-Retail trade by mail order or the Internet.

In collective or large-area commercial facilities, such as shopping centers, the commercial activity of those establishments integrated in them and not included among those authorized in the previous section will be suspended. 

In any establishment whose opening is allowed, the consumers can acquire the goods of first necessity, without being able in any case to consume any product in the establishment.

The person in charge of the establishment will avoid crowds and will control that consumers and employees maintain a safe distance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 17, the Spanish Council of Ministers passes a Royal Decree which mandates "extraordinary urgent measures to face the economic and social impact of COVID-19." Of these measures, it is made "impossible to cut off the supply of water, electricity and natural gas to users who are vulnerable, severely vulnerable or at risk of social exclusion." "The regulation also suspends the review of the maximum prices for sale to the public of bottled liquefied petroleum gases, such as butane cylinders, and of the Last Resort Rate (TUR) for natural gas, to prevent them from rising." Finally, the order "automatically extends the term of [electricity social bonuses (what supplies electricity vulnerable members of society)] until September 15, 2020."

description: "On Sunday (May 3, 2020), Spain’s Official State Gazette (BOE) published five ministerial orders setting out new measures that go into effect on Monday, May 4, 2020." Extremadura, Spain is adopting these orders. "Until now, restaurants have been allowed home delivery. Starting on Monday (May 4, 2020), customers may also pick up their orders at the restaurant, as long as safety conditions are met. There must be a plexiglass barrier separating workers from clients, and ideally only one employee per client. When this is not possible, the latter will have to remain two meters apart. Hand sanitizer must be available at the entrance and exit, as well as trash cans without lids that have to be lifted by hand. Orders must be placed ahead of time by phone or online to avoid crowds."

description: Spain announces on May 3 that starting from May 4 shops of less than 400 square meters may be opened to the public, always by appointment, which must be arranged by email or telephone. They must reserve a priority schedule for those over 65 years old, which must coincide with the time frame assigned to them for walks (although in this case it is for those over 70): from 10-12 am  and from 7-8 pm. There can be no more than one customer per employee.

description:
On May 3 Spain announces that as of 4 May it will be possible to carry out rehabilitation work on homes and premises, something that had been suspended since the state of alert came into effect. This can only be done when there is no interference between the workers and the residents or employees of the building. Also in delimited areas of the building not inhabited as long as the contact between workers and other people of the property is limited, either with exclusive circuits or with delimitation of schedules of entrance and exit for the workers.
 UPDATE: As of the 4 May it will be possible to carry out rehabilitation work on homes and premises, something that had been suspended since the state of alert came into effect.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
On May 11, all of Andalucia, except for Málaga and Granada, transition to Phase 1 of Spains deescalation plan. Due to this transition, many previous restrictions on businesses from Spains national lockdown are lifted. 

Under this new phase, the "[g]eneral opening of commercial businesses that are not part of a shopping centre" is allowed, "with 30 percent of normal clientele allowed at any time, practising social distancing with at least 2 metres between clients and with a timetable that gives preference to those over age 65." Additionally, open-air markets are allowed to reopen, but have "to have a limit of 25 percent of their previous capacity of stalls in order to assure distance between them" ("or all of the stalls can remain as long as the area of the market itself is made larger").

Furthermore, "[r]estaurants, bars and cafés can open their outside terraces at 50% capacity," and "[h]otels can open, but all of their common areas must remain closed."
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of number of customers
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: Non-essential workers (please note their occupation in the text entry where applicable)

 UPDATE: On May 18, Andalucia's Málaga and Granada transition to Phase 1.

description:
On May 11, all of Andalucia, except for Málaga and Granada, transition to Phase 1 of Spains deescalation plan. Due to this transition, many previous restrictions on businesses from Spains national lockdown are lifted. 

Under this new phase, the "[g]eneral opening of commercial businesses that are not part of a shopping centre" is allowed, "with 30 percent of normal clientele allowed at any time, practising social distancing with at least 2 metres between clients and with a timetable that gives preference to those over age 65." Additionally, open-air markets are allowed to reopen, but have "to have a limit of 25 percent of their previous capacity of stalls in order to assure distance between them" ("or all of the stalls can remain as long as the area of the market itself is made larger").

Furthermore, "[r]estaurants, bars and cafés can open their outside terraces at 50% capacity," and "[h]otels can open, but all of their common areas must remain closed."
 UPDATE: On May 18, Andalucia's Málaga and Granada transition to Phase 1.

description:
Extremadura, Spain instituted business regulation policies during Phase 1 of deescalation measures (starting May 11, 2020). "Hotels and tourist accommodation can open as long as they keep common areas such as buffet rooms closed."
UPDATE: This policy ended on May 25, 2020 with the start of Phase 2. UPDATE: The original policy had hotel and tourist accommodation common areas closed. The update, beginning May 25 (2020), allows them to open at a third of capacity.

description:
During Phase 1 (starting May 11, 2020) in Extremadura, Spain, cafes, bars, and restaurants are allowed to open their outdoor terraces with 50% capacity. Terrace areas can be increased if local town halls allow it. Hours of operation are specific to the establishment. "Maximum of ten people per table or group of tables. No serviette holders or shared olive oil bottles, etc. on tables."
UPDATE: This will continue during Phase 2, starting May 25, 2020. UPDATE: Update to the policy duration. This will continue during Phase 2 (starting May 25, 2020).

description: On May 25, all of Andalucia, except for Málaga and Granada, transition to Phase 2 of Spains deescalation plan. Due to this transition, many more previous restrictions on businesses from Spains national lockdown are lifted. Under this new phase, bars and restaurants are now also allowed to open their interior "as long as occupancy is capped at 40 percent and people are grouped around tables 2 metres apart from other customers." Additionally, "shopping malls and large premises will be able to welcome customers," with conditions being " that premises must limit the capacity to 30 percent in common areas of shopping malls and 40 percent to within the stores themselves," with social distancing being respected at all times. Finally, "[c]ommunal areas in hotels and other tourist accommodation can open to 1/3 of capacity."

description: On May 25, all of Andalucia, except for Málaga and Granada, transition to Phase 2 of Spains deescalation plan. Due to this transition, many more previous restrictions on businesses from Spains national lockdown are lifted. Under this new phase, bars and restaurants are now also allowed to open their interior "as long as occupancy is capped at 40 percent and people are grouped around tables 2 metres apart from other customers." Additionally, "shopping malls and large premises will be able to welcome customers," with conditions being " that premises must limit the capacity to 30 percent in common areas of shopping malls and 40 percent to within the stores themselves," with social distancing being respected at all times. Finally, "[c]ommunal areas in hotels and other tourist accommodation can open to 1/3 of capacity."
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is allowed to open with conditions

Due to this transition, many more previous restrictions on businesses from Spains national lockdown are lifted. Under this new phase, bars and restaurants are now also allowed to open their interior "as long as occupancy is capped at 40 percent and people are grouped around tables 2 metres apart from other customers." Additionally, "shopping malls and large premises will be able to welcome customers," with conditions being " that premises must limit the capacity to 30 percent in common areas of shopping malls and 40 percent to within the stores themselves," with social distancing being respected at all times. description: On June 8, all of Andalucia transitions to Phase 3 of Spains deescalation plan. Due to this transition, many more previous restrictions on businesses from Spains national lockdown are lifted. Under this new phase, the "occupancy on a terrace of a bar or restaurant rises from 50 percent in Phase 2 to 75 percent in Phase 3."Additionally, "Restaurants and cafes can open their indoor seating areas, with table service only [,]... numbers limited to" around half capacity, "hand sanitizer at the door," and    the preservation of social distancing. Furthermore, "nightclubs will be able to open, again at a maximum of a third of their usual capacity." On top of these loosened restrictions, "shops will be able to increase their capacity to up to 50%," and "Cinemas, theatres, shows, [and] concerts can all open" with limited capacity. Finally, "Hotels can now open their common areas including spas for up to 50 percent usual capacity," "Amusement parks, zoos, aquariums and that sort of thing can" open with limited capacity varying if visitors are inside or outside, and "Casinos, gaming halls and betting shops can open with a reduced capacity of 50 percent and maximum of 50 people."
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers

description: On June 8, all of Andalucia transitions to Phase 3 of Spains deescalation plan. Due to this transition, many more previous restrictions on businesses from Spains national lockdown are lifted. Under this new phase, the "occupancy on a terrace of a bar or restaurant rises from 50 percent in Phase 2 to 75 percent in Phase 3."Additionally, "Restaurants and cafes can open their indoor seating areas, with table service only [,]... numbers limited to" around half capacity, "hand sanitizer at the door," and    the preservation of social distancing. Furthermore, "nightclubs will be able to open, again at a maximum of a third of their usual capacity." On top of these loosened restrictions, "shops will be able to increase their capacity to up to 50%," and "Cinemas, theatres, shows, [and] concerts can all open" with limited capacity. Finally, "Hotels can now open their common areas including spas for up to 50 percent usual capacity," "Amusement parks, zoos, aquariums and that sort of thing can" open with limited capacity varying if visitors are inside or outside, and "Casinos, gaming halls and betting shops can open with a reduced capacity of 50 percent and maximum of 50 people."
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of number of customers
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On June 21, The Castilla y Leon Community finishes Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan and enters the “new normal” phase.. Under this new phase, the general opening of commercial businesses that are not part of a shopping centre is allowed, with 75% of normal clientele allowed at any time, practising social distancing with at least 1.5 metres between clients. Additionally, open-air markets are allowed to reopen, but have to have a limit of 75% of their previous capacity of stalls in order to assure distance between them.

description:
On July 6, 2020, the Community of Madrid [Spain] region's tourism website published the following guidelines for activity:

"Maximum capacity in most establishments (including shops, shopping centres, libraries, cinemas, theatres, indoor sports centres, theme parks and bullrings) is 75%.
 
Restaurants, bars and cafés can open indoor dining at 75% capacity, and are allowed to serve at the bar. Outside terraces may now open at 100% capacity.
 
Night clubs and other late night venues may now open with a maximum capacity of 40% and without dance floor.
 
Public pools, both indoor and outdoor, may open at 50% capacity.
 
Hotels are allowed to reopen their common areas up to 75% of capacity.
 
Children's parks, skate parks and outdoor activities managed by the Region of Madrid are allowed to open as long as long as there is at least 4m2 of space per person. In the Madrid mountains, picnic areas and other recreation areas will remain closed unless a maximum capacity of 75% and the proper disinfection of tables, benches and fountains can be guaranteed.
 
Large shopping centres are allowed to open at a 75% capacity (common areas can only be used for walking). Outdoor markets may also open with a maximum capacity of 75%."
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of number of customers
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On July 13, 2020, The Department of Health of the State of Catalonia in Spain ended a previous policy limiting business capacity to 50%. 

The Diari Oficial de la Generalitat de Catalunya (DOGC) has published on  August 13 a resolution of the Conselleria de Salut de la Generalitat that sets as maximum capacity allowed in service companies and stores in Lleida and six other municipalities of Lleida the equivalent of 2.5 square meters per person, instead of the limitation of 50%. UPDATE: The Diari Oficial de la Generalitat de Catalunya (DOGC) has published this Thursday a resolution of the Conselleria de Salut de la Generalitat that sets as maximum capacity allowed in service companies and stores in Lleida and six other municipalities of Lleida the equivalent of 2.5 square meters per person, instead of the limitation of 50%.

description:
For hotels and catering services: 
1. The closing time of these establishments will be at 00:00 hours, without being able to accept orders from 23:00.

description: On the 30th of October 2020, the parliament of Andalucía announced the measures adopted for each level of alert (1, 2, 3 and 4). On the same day, all regions of Andalucia went directly into level 4. Yet, that same day some of the regions were moved to other levels (this has been coded in separate entries). Among those that remained in level 4, bars and restaurants have to close at 22:30 (like all other non-essential businesses) and limit the amount of people to 30% of normal capacity indoors and 75% in terraces. The policy comes into effect on the 31st but has no clear end date.

description: The regional government has opted to close bars and restaurants in 60 municipalities from Friday at 3pm onward, and likely for a month. description:
For gambling places:
The opening of establishments and spaces dedicated to recreational and gambling activities, including gambling casinos, bingo halls, recreational rooms of slot machines, is allowed if the following rules are followed:
1. A minimum of 1.5 meters between chairs of different tables must be ensured. 
2. It will not be possible to exceed 50% of maximum capacity inside the premises. 
3. The occupancy of the tables will be a maximum of 6 people per table indoors and 10 people per table outdoors.
4. They must be closed at 2:00am.

This will beestablished starting on November 22, 2021 and will be reevaluated every few weeks.

description: The Superior Court of Justice of the Balearic Islands extends the use of Covid certificates to areas with the most concentration of people using a 3 level system. Level 1 requires a Covid certificate for restaurants and nightlife that can hold a capacity of 50 or more people. Level 2 requires a Covid certificate for shelters and tourist accommodations with shared rooms. Level 3 requires a Covid certificate for theaters and gyms. This will be enforced from Dec. 4, 2021 to Jan. 24, 2022 when it is reevaluated.

description: On March 12, the Andalucian Government announces the widespread closure of many public facilities, such as "the Alhambra de Granada, Picasso Malaga, Bellas Artes Sevilla, Medinat al-Zahra in Córdoba, Real Alcázar in Sevilla and all the 27 museums and monuments managed by the Junta de Andalucia." Additionally, the closure also applies "to the theatres and libraries of the Junta de Andalucia (regional government) and to concerts or any cultural event that they had programmed." (These measures begin an "unprecedented month of closures ahead and around Andalucia due to the coronavirus.")

description: Board of Directors of the Barcelona Area Metropolitan Transport Authority has approved, on March 31, 2020, the temporary suspension of payment of public transport rates until April 9. This implies that, as of Thursday, April 2, you will be able to travel by public transport without paying the fare. This suspension will be maintained as long as RDL 10/2020, of March 29, which restricts labor mobility to people who work in essential services, is in force. In this sense, then, the suspension will be lifted automatically on April 9, the final effective date of said restriction.

description: From April 2 to June 21 2020, the treatment boards of the prisons of Catalonia will approve that 15 people inmates in the second degree and with a 100.2 pass the confinement for coronavirus in their home temporarily, during the emergency. It is about 15% of all prisoners in these circumstances. It is the first time that the prisons of the Generalitat have proposed a measure of these characteristics, in accordance with a non-restrictive interpretation of the Prison Regulations.

description:
From April 2, 2020 the service areas of the motorways of Catalonia, both owned by the Generalitat and the State, will remain open during the period of state of alarm. This measure wants to facilitate forced mobility during the coronavirus emergency.

Thus, the service areas located on the highways: C-16, Vallvidrera tunnels, Sant Cugat - Terrassa-Manresa and Cadí tunnel; C-32, Garraf and Maresme tunnels, C-33 Barcelona - Montmeló; AP-2, Zaragoza - Mediterranean, AP-7 La Jonquera - Salou, will be open during their usual hours.

description: On May 11, all of Andalucia, except for Málaga and Granada, transition to Phase 1 of Spains deescalation plan. Due to this transition, many previous restrictions on government services from Spains national lockdown are lifted. This includes the fact that museums can now "can open at 30% capacity," and the allowance for libraries to reopen, as long as they house "a third of their capacity at a time" and do not host any activities."

description: On May 18, The Valencian Community enters Phase 1 of Spain’s 4-phase de escalation plan. Due to this transition, some previous limitations on government services are lifted. Museums can now open at 30% capacity and will have free entry until the end of the year. Also libraries can reopen, as long as they house a third of their capacity at a time and do not host any activities.

description: As part of Asturias's (Spain) transition to the New Normal (in compliance and coordination with national efforts), supervised visits to residential centers for people with disabilities and homes for the elderly will be permitted. However, these visits must comply with the following measures: they are limited to one person per resident, the use of PPE will be mandatory, social distancing must remain in effect, and crowd control must be exercised by the administrative staff of the centers.

description:
On June 8, all of Andalucia transitions to Phase 3 of Spains deescalation plan. Due to this transition, many more previous restrictions on government services from Spains national lockdown are lifted:

- "Libraries may be used (both for cultural activities and for study), provided that they do not exceed 50% of their capacity and that they comply with all the other measures established in the Order."

- "Museums may allow the public to visit their collections and temporary exhibitions, as well as to participate in cultural or educational activities, as long as they do not exceed 50% of the museum's capacity and the groups do not exceed 20 people, among other restrictions."
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: Spain announced that all state museums managed by the Ministry of Culture and Sport will reopen to the public on Tuesday 9 June, 2020 during standard opening times. The museums will temporarily adapt their exhibitions and reduce the number of rooms that can be visited in order to comply with prevention measures and recommendations from the Ministry of Health. UPDATE: The original policy closed all State museums in Madrid until further notice starting March 11. Now they will reopen from June 9, 2020.

description: On June 15, five provinces of The Castilla y Leon Community (Valladolid, Palencia, Burgos, Zamora y Leon) enters Phase 3 of Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan. Due to this transition, some previous limitations on government services are lifted. Museums, cinemas and libraries can now open at 50% of their total capacity. Also, parks’ playgrounds for kids re-open with a maximum capacity of 50%.

Due to this transition, some previous limitations on government services are lifted. People can gather at beaches in groups of up to 20 people
 UPDATE: On June 21, The Castilla y Leon Community finished Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan and all the nine provinces entered the “New Normal” phase.

Due to this transition, some previous limitations on government services are lifted. People can gather at beaches in groups of up to 25 people. Parks’ playgrounds for kids re-open with a maximum capacity of 75% . All the squares, venues and bullfighting facilities will be able to carry out their bullfighting activity as long as they have pre-assigned seats and 75% of the authorized capacity is not exceeded

description:
On March 9, the Interterritorial Council of the National Health System agrees to " a set of measures for areas that are in the [midst]... of significant community transmission. At the moment, only the Community of Madrid, the city of Vitoria and the town of Labastida are in this situation." These measures include:

1. Measures in the educational field (i.e. "Suspension of face-to-face teaching activity at all educational levels" and suspension "of complementary educational activities."

2. Recommendations in the workplace (i.e. "Carrying out teleworking whenever possible" and scheduling flexible " and staggered shifts to reduce worker concentrations."

3. Protection measures for specific populations for the entire Spanish territory (i.e. "Promote home care for the elderly.")

4. Other measures of a general nature (i.e. "People who start respiratory symptoms and / or fever are recommended to stay at home.")
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Madrid (Madrid); Vitoria (Basque Country) and Labastida (Basque Country)

description:
From March 3, 2020, the following measures will be implemented until March 27,2020:
Sports events in Catalonia (professional and non-professional) will be held behind closed doors. In the case of events in which minors participate, players may be accompanied by adults.
Collective activities that involve gatherings of more than 1000 people, whether held in closed or open spaces, will be suspended or postponed.  When such events are held in spaces with a capacity of less than 1000 people, they may be held only if they occupy one third or less of the maximum authorised capacity. This provision is aimed at ensuring sufficient spatial separation between participants.
These restrictive measures will apply to public, recreational and leisure events, as well as cultural, religious or similar activities, regardless of whether they are offered by a public or private proprietor, operator or organiser.
The measures that apply to the public administration will be established shortly. In this case, the Directorate-General for the Civil Service will issue instructions to all affected institutions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
On March 9, the Interterritorial Council of the National Health System agrees to " a set of measures for areas that are in the [midst]... of significant community transmission. At the moment, only the Community of Madrid, the city of Vitoria and the town of Labastida are in this situation." These measures include:

1. Measures in the educational field (i.e. "Suspension of face-to-face teaching activity at all educational levels" and suspension "of complementary educational activities."

2. Recommendations in the workplace (i.e. "Carrying out teleworking whenever possible" and scheduling flexible " and staggered shifts to reduce worker concentrations."

3. Protection measures for specific populations for the entire Spanish territory (i.e. "Promote home care for the elderly.")

4. Other measures of a general nature (i.e. "People who start respiratory symptoms and / or fever are recommended to stay at home.")
 UPDATE: On March 12, the Spanish Interterritorial Council agrees to expand the scope of the March 9 Covid distancing measures to affect the entire nation.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Madrid (Madrid); Vitoria (Basque Country) and Labastida (Basque Country)

description: On March 12, the president of the Generalitat Valenciana, Ximo Puig, informed that all professional sports matches must be played behind closed doors. This measure would be instilled until the sanitary risk lowers. Additionally, Puig mentioned that Fallas, a traditional celebration held anually, is suspended until further notice. These measures will enter into force on the 16th of March 2020. UPDATE: On March 14, the National Government of Spain announces a nationwide state of emergency. Due to this, all mass gatherings are prohibited. This new national mandate replaces the previous, Valencia made some specific rules related to gatherings.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain on March 14 suspends the opening to the public of museums, archives, libraries, monuments, as well as of the premises and establishments where public shows take place. Hotel and restaurant activities are suspended, and home delivery services can be exclusively provided. Festivals, parades and popular festivals are also suspended.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: From March 14, 2020, the government of Aragon implemented a restriction of mass gatherings by suspending, in the Autonomous Community of Aragon, the collective acts in closed or open spaces of public, recreational and leisure shows, cultural, religious, sports or similar activities, regardless of whether they are offered by a public owner, manager or organizer or private. Exceptionally, as long as whoever appears as the owner, manager or organizer guarantees the non-existence of risk for the achievement of the public health objectives object of this Order, such acts may be held when they do not involve or may involve a concentration equal to or greater than 200 people. In the case of activities in spaces with limited capacity with an expected number of attendees of less than 200 people, they may only be held if a maximum of one third of the authorized capacity is occupied, in order to guarantee an adequate space of separation between the participants
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From March 14, 2020, the government of Aragon implemented a restriction of mass gatherings by suspending, in the Autonomous Community of Aragon, the collective acts in closed or open spaces of public, recreational and leisure shows, cultural, religious, sports or similar activities, regardless of whether they are offered by a public owner, manager or organizer or private. Exceptionally, as long as whoever appears as the owner, manager or organizer guarantees the non-existence of risk for the achievement of the public health objectives object of this Order, such acts may be held when they do not involve or may involve a concentration equal to or greater than 200 people. In the case of activities in spaces with limited capacity with an expected number of attendees of less than 200 people, they may only be held if a maximum of one third of the authorized capacity is occupied, in order to guarantee an adequate space of separation between the participants
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 14, the National Government of Spain announces a nationwide state of emergency. Due to this, all mass gatherings are prohibited. This new national mandate replaces the previous, Castilla y León made some specific rules related to gatherings.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 15, the Mayor of the Andalucia town of Seville, Juan Espadas, "announced that the Seville Spring Fair would be postponed until September 2020. No exact dates were given but it will probably be the second fortnight in September 2020. It is the first time that it has not taken place in the Spring since the fair was founded in 1847." UPDATE: On April 24, the Mayor of Seville "announced that the plan to hold the 2020 Spring Fair (Feria de Abril) in September has now been abandoned."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On March 12, 2020, the parliament of Galicia announced measures to fight against the pandemic. Among those, cultural and leisure events indoors are restricted to 500. The policy comes into effect on the 16th of March, and for a period of 14 days.

description: On March 28, 2020 the Primavera Sound festival has announced its postponement due to the health emergency caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. It is the largest Spanish festival that has made this decision to date, and it has gone from being held in the Parc del Fòrum from June 3 to 7 to August 26 to 30. Tickets already purchased will continue to be valid for the new dates, the decision, taken in coordination with the Generalitat de Catalunya.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 30, the Ministry of Health releases an order that "prohibits wakes and restricts funeral ceremonies to limit the spread and contagion of COVID-19." Under this order, "all wakes, regardless of the cause of death and whether they are held in public or private facilities, including private homes," are prohibited. Additionally, the "celebration of religious services or civil funeral ceremonies will be postponed until
the end of the alarm state," with "the burial or dismissal for cremation of [a]... deceased person [being]... restricted to a maximum of three relatives or close friends," with the addition of "the minister of worship or assimilated person of the respective confession for the
practice of funeral rites of farewell to the deceased." Other measures, such as adherence to social distancing, are also imposed.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain on March 14 suspends the opening to the public of museums, archives, libraries, monuments, as well as of the premises and establishments where public shows take place. Hotel and restaurant activities are suspended, and home delivery services can be exclusively provided. Festivals, parades and popular festivals are also suspended. UPDATE: The only home delivery policy has now been relaxed. Spain announces on May 3 that starting from May 4 restaurants are allowed to sell food that can be picked up, provided that security conditions are met: There must be a screen or bar that separates employees from customers. Preferably, one employee should serve each customer and, when this is not possible, the customers should keep a separation distance of two meters from each other. At the entrance of the establishment, there must be authorized hydroalcoholic gels with virucidal activity and at the exit, litter bins with a non-manually operated lid, equipped with a garbage bag. Orders must be made in advance by phone or online to avoid crowds.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
Spain has a four-phase system for reopening, which authorities are applying at different speeds in different regions.

Most of Spain moved into phase around May 10th. Up to 10 people are allowed to meet together, provided they wear masks and socially distance, while bars and restaurants can open outdoor seating at half capacity. Cinemas, museums and theatres are also opening at reduced capacity.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On May 11, all of Andalucia, except for Málaga and Granada, transition to Phase 1 of Spains deescalation plan. Due to this transition, many previous limitations on mass gatherings are lifted. "Getting together with up to ten people is allowed as long as no one involved is in a vulnerable or at-risk group or has been ill within the previous period, and as long as physical distances are maintained. Wakes or memorial services are also permitted with a limit on attendees." Furthermore, "[p]laces of worship can open at 30% capacity." Finally, "[c]ultural events for up to 30 people can be held indoors at 30% of the venue’s capacity," while 
"[c]ultural events for up to 200 people can be held outdoors."
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Government of Castilla and Leon, by order SAN / 295/2020 from March 11, recommended to suspend activities in outdoor spaces that can bring together a large number of people, such as concerts, street markets, flea markets, fairs, pilgrimages, killings and the like.

This policy ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19. UPDATE: The original policy was supposed to end on March 26, but it actually ended on March 14 with the Royal Decree 463/2020 that declared the national state of alarm for the management of the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19.

description: On May 18, The Valencian Community enters Phase 1 of Spain’s 4-phase de escalation plan. Due to this transition, many previous limitations on mass gatherings are lifted. Social gatherings up to ten people are now allowed as long as no one involved is in a vulnerable or at-risk group or has been ill within the previous period, and as long as physical distances are maintained. Wakes or memorial services are also permitted with a limit on attendees. Also, churches can open up to ⅓ of capacity. Furthermore, places of worship can open at 30% capacity. Finally, cultural events for up to 30 people can be held indoors at 30% of the venue’s capacity, while cultural events for up to 200 people can be held outdoors.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On May 25, all of Andalucia, except for Málaga and Granada, transition to Phase 2 of Spains deescalation plan. Due to this transition, many more previous restrictions on mass gatherings are lifted. For example, "[c]ultural events can have a maximum of 400 people outdoors and 50 indoors," while "business meetings and conferences can now be attended by up to 50 people as long as social distancing is observed." Additionally, weddings "are allowed for up to 100 people outdoors and 50 indoors," and can only "include a ceremony and not a banquet." Furthermore, for churches, the "capacity will be increased to 50%, instead of the 30% of the previous phase," and "[r]ecreational swimming pools can open up to 1/3 of capacity, but changing room showers cannot be used and safety distancing must always be guaranteed." Finally, the limit to "private gatherings in Phase 2 is now 15 people," with the "limit on numbers attending funeral[/]wakes is 15 indoors and 25 outdoors; for burials the maximum is 25."
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On May 25, The Castilla y León Community enters Phase 1 of Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan. Due to this transition, many previous limitations on mass gatherings are lifted. Social gatherings up to ten people are now allowed as long as no one involved is in a vulnerable or at-risk group or has been ill within the previous period, and as long as physical distances are maintained. Also, cultural events for up to 30 people can be held indoors at 30% of the venue’s capacity, while cultural events for up to 200 people can be held outdoors.

description:
On May 25, all of Andalucia, except for Málaga and Granada, transition to Phase 2 of Spains deescalation plan. Due to this transition, many more previous restrictions on mass gatherings are lifted. For example, "[c]ultural events can have a maximum of 400 people outdoors and 50 indoors," while "business meetings and conferences can now be attended by up to 50 people as long as social distancing is observed." Additionally, weddings "are allowed for up to 100 people outdoors and 50 indoors," and can only "include a ceremony and not a banquet." Furthermore, for churches, the "capacity will be increased to 50%, instead of the 30% of the previous phase," and "[r]ecreational swimming pools can open up to 1/3 of capacity, but changing room showers cannot be used and safety distancing must always be guaranteed." Finally, the limit to "private gatherings in Phase 2 is now 15 people," with the "limit on numbers attending funeral[/]wakes is 15 indoors and 25 outdoors; for burials the maximum is 25."


 UPDATE: On May 28, the National Government of Spain announces that, on June 1, Málaga and Granada will transition to Phase 2 of Spains deescalation plan, meaning all of Andalucia will now subject to the lifting of business restrictions allowed under phase 2 (see May 25 policy for specifics on restriction liftings).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On June 1, The Valencian Community enters Phase 2 of Spain’s 4-phase de escalation plan. Due to this transition, many previous limitations on mass gatherings are lifted. The limit of private gatherings is now 15 people. The limit on people attending funerals or wakes is 15 indoors and 25 outdoors. Furthermore, for churches, the capacity will be increased to 50%. Weddings are now allowed for up to 100 people outdoors and 50 indoors. Additionally, recreational swimming pools can open up to ⅓ of capacity, but changing rooms showers cannot be used and safety distancing must always be guaranteed. Finally, business meetings and conferences can now be attended by up to 50 people as long as social distancing is observed.

description: On June 15, The Valencian Community enters Phase 3 of Spain’s 4-phase de escalation plan. Due to this transition, some previous limitations on mass gatherings are lifted. The limit of private gatherings is now 20 people. Also, people can go to the beach in groups of up to 20 people. The limit on people attending funerals or wakes is 25 indoors and 50 outdoors. Furthermore, for churches and wedding ceremonies, the capacity will be increased to 75%. Additionally, recreational swimming pools can open up to 75% of capacity and business meetings and conferences can now be attended by up to 100 people as long as social distancing is observed. Finally, cultural shows and events can take place with audiences of less than 80 indoors and 800 outdoors (seated). Theme parks can also open with up to 800 people.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description:
On June 8, all of Andalucia transitions to Phase 3 of Spains deescalation plan. Due to this transition, many more previous restrictions on mass gatherings from Spains national lockdown are lifted:

- People can now meet up in general groups of 20 individuals.

- "Work conferences can have up to 80 attendees."

- "Weddings, baptism and first communions can now go ahead with 75 percent of the venue’s capacity and up to 75 people when indoors and 150 people when outdoors."

- A maximum  of "50 people in open spaces or 25 in closed spaces" can attend a funeral.

- "Leisure activities for children and young people may now be carried out, limiting the number of participants to 50% of the usual capacity (with a maximum of 200 people) if the activities take place outdoors, and to 30% of capacity (with a maximum of 80 people) if they take place indoors."
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: On June 21, The Castilla y Leon Community finishes Spain’s 4-phase de-escalation plan and enters the “new normal” phase. Due to this transition, some previous limitations on businesses are lifted. The practice of non-federated physical and sports activity, outdoors, may be carried out individually or collectively, without physical contact, respecting the safety and hygiene measures established by the health authorities or, failing that, alternative physical protection measures. , hand hygiene and respiratory etiquette. In conventional outdoor sports facilities, physical-sports activity can be carried out, without physical contact, with the maximum limit of 80% of the maximum occupancy allowed in sports practice and in covered sports facilities and sports centers sports activity can be carried out in groups , without physical contact, and as long as 75% of the maximum occupancy allowed in sports is not exceeded

description:
1.	Wakes may be held in all types of facilities, public or private, with a maximum limit, at any time, of fifty people in outdoor spaces or twenty-five people in enclosed spaces, whether or not they live together, and provided that seventy-five percent of their capacity is not exceeded.
2.	Participation in the entourage for the burial or farewell for cremation of the deceased person is restricted to a maximum of fifty people, including relatives and where appropriate, including the minister of worship or assimilated person of the respective confession for the practice of the funeral rites of farewell of the deceased person.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description:
1.	Attendance at places of worship may not exceed seventy-five percent of its capacity. The maximum capacity must be published in a visible place of the space intended for worship. In the event that the minimum safety distance cannot be maintained, maximum separation must be sought and the mask must be used.
2.	The exterior of the buildings or the public road may not be used for the celebration of acts of worship.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description:
1.	Wedding ceremonies may be held in all types of facilities, public or private, either in outdoor spaces or enclosed spaces, provided that seventy-five percent of their capacity is not exceeded. In the event that the minimum safety distance cannot be maintained, maximum separation must be sought and the mask must be used.
2. When ceremonies are held inside places of worship, then it may not exceed seventy-five percent of its capacity. The maximum capacity must be published in a visible place of the space intended for worship. In the event that the minimum safety distance cannot be maintained, maximum separation must be sought and the mask must be used.
3.	The celebrations that may take place after the wedding ceremony and that involve some type of hotel and restaurant service, will also be restricted.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Spain held a meeting of central and regional health officials known as the Inter-Territorial Council of Spain’s National Health System on Sept 30. The new health regulations were published on October 1st. 
The new measures entail restricting movement in municipalities with a population of 100,000 or more that meet three criteria: a 14-day cumulative incidence of coronavirus cases exceeding 500 per 100,000 inhabitants, at least 10% of PCR tests coming back positive, and more than 35% of intensive care unit (ICU) beds taken up by Covid-19 patients.

The restrictions involve  reducing the size of social gatherings,  among other measures.

Regional governments are expected to officialize them as well in the coming 48 hours by Oct 3rd. The regional governments have the obligation to observe them.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
For wakes and burials:
4.1.	Wakes may be held in all types of facilities, public or private, with a capacity of 30% and a maximum limit of 25 people in outdoor spaces or 15 people in enclosed spaces, whether or not they live together and provided that the safety distance can be guaranteed.
4.2.	Participation in the burial or farewell for cremation of the deceased person, is restricted to a maximum of 25 people in outdoor spaces or 15 people in closed spaces.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
For celebrations:
1. Non-religious ceremonies may be performed in all types of facilities, public or private, either in outdoor spaces or enclosed spaces, provided that it does not exceed 1/3 of its capacity and with a maximum of 25 people in outdoor spaces or 15 people in closed spaces, including family members and relatives, and that the interpersonal distance of safety and hygiene measures can be guaranteed.
2. The celebrations that involve hotel and restaurant service can also have a maximum of 25 people in outdoor spaces or 15 people in closed spaces, between relatives.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Measures relating to recreational/leisure activities for young people and child establishments:
1. In recreational playgrounds, in the open air, bouncy castles, slides and other playgrounds, the safety and hygiene measures established by the health authorities for the prevention of Covid-19 must be respected, maintaining cleanliness at least daily, limiting the capacity to 50% and the safety distance of 1.5 meters must be obeyed, except family members or children belonging to the same group.
2. Children's entertainment venues in enclosed spaces must ensure frequent cleaning and that there is no exchange of objects between the users. They may not exceed the capacity of 50%.
3.	During the development of the educational leisure activities, the participants will be organized in groups of up to a maximum of 10, including the monitor.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
For sporting events:
1. The celebration of sporting events, training or non-professional sports competitions held in sports facilities may be held with a maximum public capacity of 30%, and with a limit of 150 people attending.
2. Sports events or competitions that take place outdoors in natural spaces or on public roads will be developed to avoid crowds. In any natural area or on public roads, the capacity cannot exceed more than 30%, and no more than 150 people.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
For concerts and festivals:
1. Concerts and festivals may only be held in venues that are part of the Valencian Music Catalogue 20/21 in its Section of Rooms of regular programming, which may not exceed 1/3 of its capacity.
2. The outdoor terraces of these establishments may be opened to the public with 50% capacity.
3. The space intended for a dance floor or similar, may not be used for normal use, but may be used to install tables or groups of tables.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
"The Basque Country in Spain dictates Decree 44/2020 on the 10th of December,2020 that includes: Limitation of the permanence of groups of people in public and private spaces. The number should not exceed the maximum number of six people, except in the case of cohabitants,
and without prejudice to the exceptions established in relation to dependencies, facilities, and establishments open to the public, or with respect to minors or dependents. The Decree terminates on the 11th of January, 2021. "
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On the 29th of October 2020, the parliament of Andalucia announced several measures to fight against the spread of COVID-19, effective on the 30th at 00:00. Among the measures, gatherings (both indoors and outdoors) are restricted to 6 people. The policy has no clear end date. UPDATE: The original policy had no clear end date, now it has been announced it will continue in place until the 24th of November at least. UPDATE: The policy has been extended again until December 10th. UPDATE: The policy has been extended until January 10th (with exceptions for up to 10 people meetings on the 24th/25th/31st of December)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Measures relating to swimming pools and beaches:
1. Swimming pools for recreational use, hotel pools, tourist accommodation and swimming pools in urbanizations must respect the limit of 30% of their capacity both in terms of access and recreational practice. The changing areas may be used. But you will not be able to use the showers or water sources.
2. Access to the beaches is allowed to walk or do physical and sports activity outdoors, maintaining the measures of physical distancing and hygiene and prevention, always within the limitation to freedom of movement and mobility and the maximum number of people who can stay in a group.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: As part of its declaration of emergency, Spain on March 14 rules for its public transport, that in those services in which the ticket grants a seat or cabin, the transport operators will take the necessary measures to ensure the maximum possible separation between the passengers. (Article 14)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
From March 14, 2020, the government of Aragon is implementing new social distancing mesures by :

1. Asking people to avoid crowded places where an interpersonal safety distance of 2 meters cannot be maintained

e) Limiting the number of companions of patients who attend medical consultations.

i) Encouraging meeting and working by videoconference.

a) Suspending the opening of non-residential centers for the elderly of a recreational nature, such as homes, clubs and centers for conviviality and leisure. 

b) Limiting visits to one person per resident in residential centers for the elderly and for people with disabilities, at the time determined by the address of the center. This limitation will apply except for individual circumstances, in which additional measures of care and humanization that will be adopted by the management of the center are appropriate. 

c) Not allowing access to residential centers for the elderly and people with disabilities to people with symptoms of acute respiratory infection 

d) Suspending group or collective activities aimed at the elderly and people with disabilities.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Board of Directors of the Barcelona Area Metropolitan Transport Authority has approved, on March 31, 2020, the temporary suspension of payment of public transport rates until April 9. This implies that, as of Thursday, April 2, you will be able to travel by public transport without paying the fare. This suspension will be maintained as long as RDL 10/2020, of March 29, which restricts labor mobility to people who work in essential services, is in force. In this sense, then, the suspension will be lifted automatically on April 9, the final effective date of said restriction.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On April 13, to coincide with the loosening of lockdown measures allowing non-essential workers to return to their jobs, the Government of Spain publishes guidelines that workers and workplaces must follow to ensure safety from infection. These guidelines include that the "maximum capacity must allow meeting the interpersonal distance requirement," and that measures, in order for workspaces to operate, "reinforced sanitation tasks must be undertaken" every day.

description:
Spain's health minister said that those returning to work on Monday (April 13th)  will have to follow strict social distancing rules.
"It is very important to maintain a social distance of a minimum of one meter, preferably of two meters, during your commute to work," he said, adding the same measures need to be guaranteed in work places and any "business that is open to the public."
type_sub_cat: Keep a distance of some other distance not listed above. Please note the distance in meters in the text entry.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Spain prohibits religious services, civil ceremonies and vigils and restricts funeral ceremonies to 3 family members/relatives starting from March 30 - those attending funerals have to keep a 1 m distance UPDATE: Religious services and civil ceremonies have been allowed in declaration on the state of emergency from March 14, starting from March 30, funerals are limited to 3 people, religious services or civil ceremonies are banned
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: Extremadura, Spain is regulating physical exercise in public areas from May 2, 2020 until Extremadura enters Phase 1 on May 11, 2020. "Those who practice sports will not be able to use any mode of transport to, for example, reach a park far from their home where they want to run or train with a bicycle. They will have to do so in a place they can reach on foot or with their bicycle, always staying within their municipality. The shared bicycles available for use in many Spanish cities cannot be used to do sport." "[With] sport, “a minimum interpersonal distance of at least two meters should be maintained with others.” The rules indicate that crowded areas should also be avoided." There may be checks on people’s behaviors but details are unknown.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
